title: Ray
summary: Ray Donovan, a professional "fixer" for the rich and famous in Los Angeles, can make anyone's problems disappear except those created by his own family.

reviews.content: Ray Donovan is about a fixer (Liev Schreiber) for Hollywood elites like celebrities, athletes, business moguls, etc. It's dark, gritty and just an overall fun show. The acting is so good here, the entire cast really makes you invested in their characters and care what happens to them. I've loved Ray Donovan from the very first episode of season 1 until the end. But like most here have already said, the last few seasons and the movie are not as good but still not bad. The only bad part of the show are his kids, especially Bridget. They just come off as spoiled and entitled and don't appreciate anything their dad does for them. Not too much to say other than this show was fantastic, if you don't believe me just read through the reviews. Most people who've seen it love it!

Ray Donovan is a flat out awesome tv show! It really is an incredible show, especially the earlier seasons! The last two seasons aren't quite as good but still worth watching. Liev Schreiber is perfect as Ray Donovan and leads an amazing all around cast that are all at the top of their game here. I absolutely recommend this show to anyone who loves a good drama with plenty of action!

Take a shot if a character says:What?SureIt doesn't matterGet in the carIf you really want to raise the stakes, take a half shot every time a character says:F. youGo F. yourselfYou may want to have medical professionals standing by for the last two.This show started off great. It got boring during the middle seasons, but season 6 was very good. I have mixed emotions about season 7. They provided a lot of interesting back story for a few characters, but they left a lot of loose threads at the end.The whole series showed way too much of Ray's daughter. She got somewhat interesting in Season 6, but then I, once again, lost interest in her during season 7.I'm glad Ray's son wasn't shown much during the last few seasons. He was an annoying character from the beginning.Overall, it's a good show if you can stick with the boring bits.

reviews.review_title: A modern crime epic chock full of loathsome antiheros, almost perfect.
reviews.content: I so want to love this series, as I did GoT, Weeds, and The Wire. The comparison to The Sopranos is apt, great writing, soundtrack, casting and acting. Completely spoiling the magic however is the character and the actor playing Ray's daughter. She's so absolutely dreadful, I stopped watching probably at season 4. I get that she's supposed to be a sniveling brat, but she makes every scene she's in unwatchable. Going back several times since Covid, Ive tried to binge watch, and just can't get thru without fastforwarding which is exhausting.Everyone is odious in their own special way, even the good guys like Terry and Bunchie- its what makes it so fun to watch. Balancing the general psychopathic insanity by showing the characters' humanity without going saccharine makes it fine, though it teeters on the brink at times. I have never seen Jon Voight in a better role than Micky .Donovan since Midnight Cowboy. Steven Bauer is fabulous, so nice to see him. I ignored the more ignoble parts of his career in one dreadful 80's-90's straight to Dvd classic after another; he requently wore headbands. So many good roles for character actors and trrific cameo performances from Roseanne Arquette and Elliott Gould to Ian McShane. Before watching Ray, I really wasn't exposed to Lieb Shrieber, and what a marvelous performance he's had carrying the lead. Kudos to everyone on the team for a job well done. Ever story has its arc and if this lasted 7 seasons, I'm sure it's creatively past its use by date, though i might be sad if I ever get past Season 4.

My brother convinced me to subscribe to Paramount to watch this series, which I obviously did and binge watched over the past few weeks. That is a looot of watching. I can honestly say that my interest never flagged.The delightful cameos by the many guest stars helped but the performances of Schreiber and Voight were superlative. Reaffirmed their talent as A-list performers.Voight is an inspiration!! His effervescent energy at 80+ years is truly unbelievable. Wow!!!Series 5 was a disaster. Glad to be rid of Abby, but what an interminably boring way to be rid of her. An entire series. Much fast forwarding required. Honestly her and the daughter Brigitte were the only downside to the series. Annoying to the core. Other female characters were great, and Sandy in the final few series was sensational. One of the best characters ever. In any series!I highly recommend this series. Captivatingly brilliant!!

Ray Donovan is a fantastic series, filled with superb performances, writing and directing. Liev Schreiber as Ray Donovan and Jon Voight as Mickey Donovan in particular, give two performances for the ages. The rest of the cast is outstanding too. While the show never gets quite as riveting as the first 3 seasons, it is still one of the best TV Shows, that I have ever seen.

Ray Donovan is absolutely awesome! It's just a flat out incredible show, especially the earlier seasons! Liev Schreiber is perfect as Ray Donovan and leads an amazing all around cast that are all at the top of their game here. I absolutely recommend this show to anyone who loves a good drama with plenty of action!

Greetings from Lithuania."Ray Donovan" is definitely the best drama of this year. The show is so rich in characters, and subplots that it's a joy to watch every scene. This is the most interesting family drama since "Sopranos". Yes, it's that good. It touches themes that you won't see in regular shows, and it approaches them in gritty yet very realistic and human way. I think "Ray Donovan" will definitely win some big awards, and will gain a cult status pretty soon.Overall, if you are tired from all standard shows, and want to watch something true to life, "Ray Donovan" is not to be missed.

Just finished binge watching this show and i gotta tell ya, it's been a long ride. The storyline is gr8, the drama aswell and it's also packed with action!What are you waiting for and prepare yourself for this masterpiece!

The show really started off well, interesting premise, good story lines through seasons 1-4. Then Season 5 happened and sucked the life out of the show. It's as if everyone decided to go on some sort of hiatus and the show just bottoms out at that point. What were they thinking? It's no wonder that the series was abruptly cancelled after Season 7. I guess the network was afraid of another Season 5. Never could understand the point of killing off the Abby character!

The previews and billboards of this Showtime series did nothing to intrigue or attract me as a viewer. I watched the pilot merely because there was nothing else to watch and I was slightly curious, and because I really like Liev as an actor, and Jon Voight is always great. I got hooked because of the underlying forces at work that shape the personalities of Ray and his brothers. It was a total shocker and gripping, believable surprise. I really wanted this show to win more awards. It is the only show I'm aware of that has tackled one of the most difficult social issues of our time. It is so well written one must wonder if the writers are close to people who are wrestling with these issues. This is a must-see series and it really deserves more recognition, not only for the excellent writing, but the casting and acting and directing. Ray Donovan is Showtime's best new drama!

I'm watching the entire series for the 2nd time and again it amazes me how well the brothers and father have been selected. These actors really make a disfunctional family work. Superb storyline, keeps one wondering "how would he get out of this one?" The solutions are very creative. Well done writers!

So I was bored last week and needed a show to watch. I decided to skim through Showtime and decided on giving Ray Donovan a try. Well here I am four days later and I'm on episode 10 of season 6. Wowzer does this show blow me away. I love the grittiness, the laughs, the emotional value and the edge of your seat action that I get from this show. I read alot of the reviews on here and kept hearing about how season 5 was a disappointment. Well I couldn't agree less. Every season has been amazing. I'm actually dreading that I'm coming up to the end. Happy to read that they have already started production of season 7. This show is a win in my book. Highly recommend. And it doesn't hurt that I am a Boston girl, born and raised. Love shows that make me feel at home.
Micky and aunt Sandy you have my heart, truly the best characters. Each n evry character has done a great job, you really get attached to the characters and the story.
I just want to say that Abby Donovan is the most annoying character on the face of the earth. Also, Mickey Donovan is hilarious and Jon Voight is a legend. Watch this show, it's fantastic.

reviews.review_title: Best family drama since The Sopranos?
reviews.content: I watched the first episode of Ray Donovan without knowing much about the plot or characters. Liev Schrieber is fantastic in the lead role and is reminiscent of Tony Soprano in that he is a dark, violent lead male under constant stress who is protective and nurturing of those he loves, while at the same time projecting an aura of violence and danger to those who would cross him. One scene, where Ray menaces a man who double-crosses him is particularly chilling. The supporting characters are also very solid. Paula Malcomson, (Ray's wife Abby) under-utilized in Deadwood is here allowed to flex her acting muscles in several scenes with Schreiber. Also in the show is the great Jon Voigt, who plays Ray's father. The conflict between them is set up right away in this first episode and one senses an Oedipal confrontation coming somewhere down the line. Most series start out weak and get better as the show grows and develops. This show, however, started out with a bang. If it gets BETTER it will very soon be the best show on television.

reviews.review_title: Great writing, great acting, immersive, engaging
reviews.content: This is a solid drama - with the lead character helping upper crusty (mostly) Hollywood types safeguard their positions in society. In addition to the basic premise, the lives (and issues) of the Donovan family are explored.Ray Donovan drives a good portion of this drama - but as a strong silent type - it is the lives of his family, associates and clients that keep the viewers fully engaged. Jon Voight delivers a remarkable performance as the troublesome father - and I think it is his role that helps elevate this series past a 6-7 rating. He really spices things up.The lives of his brothers (Bunchy, Terry and Daryll) - while not compelling in themselves; add a real-life substance to the series - helping make this a serious drama.I think the series suffers when we delve into Ray's immediate family - his wife (Abby) and his children (Bridget and Conor). You might have a different take on their roles but I personally found them uninteresting and often irritating.Abby doesn't seem to have a real role - she's not quite a mother, not a knowing/wise wife - but instead comes across as a needy teenager. Her scenes are passable and still somewhat watchable because of Paula Malcomson's impressive acting ability.Conor, the son, completely forgettable. His life doesn't engage nor does it irritate - it's simply meh - filler material.Bridget, on the other hand, plays the typical (Hollywood) epically annoying teenage girl. You will want to fast forward anytime she appears at 100x speed but... you'll miss out on characters like Marvin and Cookie. So you have to put up with her (it won't be easy). Since the rest of the series is so strong, Bridget is unable to single-handedly destroy the series (which Hollywood-written teenage girls often do).I am reviewing this after watching 3 seasons. I'm tempted to rate this a 6 because I dislike the epically irritating Bridget character so much. But there is so much more going on, so many other great characters, so many outstanding performances (from strong emotions to nuances) that this series is easily an 8 - despite the annoying teenager.May update review later (since I plan on watching all 7 years). It's been bingeable good!

I have watched every episode and find it funny since season 1 Ray basically spends his day with a coffee at home then to the gym for a whisky,then to the office for a whisky,then to various potential clients for a whisky.Then comes home at night and has a whisky and nurses various wounds he got throughout his day and then wakes up and repeats again the next day. So in summation tough guys can get stabbed,beat up,and shot and they can just go home and take off the bloody clothes and have drinks and be recovered by morning all on an empty stomach.Too funny.

reviews.review_title: Looks like another hit Original from Showtime
reviews.content: I had to review this show after seeing the current reviews posted. At the moment there are 4 written reviews and all but one are HIGHLY critical and undeserved in my opinion.The casting is brilliant. Acting is right on. Writing is great. Direction is fantastic. Cinematography is top notch. Am I watching a different show? I could go on with praises of all the elements of Ray Donovan, but it would just be repetitive and monotonous, and I would run out of synonyms.I truly think Showtime has it's next hit to fill in the gap left by Dexter next season.I don't want to go into arcs, plot, etc. and spoil anything. I just wanted to make sure there was another positive review posted, so even more people give Ray Donovan a chance. Believe me, if you have liked Showtime's other amazing Originals, you'll love it as much as I do.

This is another brilliant show on showtime. All top notch actors with a solid storyline. You won't get bored for a minute. A lot of action, violence and sex. All ingredients are there to make this a long lasting show. Liev Schreiber and Jon Voight excel in their performances. While Ray Donovan tries to fix the problems of the rich he can't get to manage his own family that drifts aways from him. His brothers all have their own problems and they all contribute to make this series more then enjoyable. You can feel the pain dripping of Terry and Bunchy Donovan. I think this is one of the better dramas from the last years and I hope it will continue for many years.

..looking back have no clue why this show slipped past.. now only into watching the start of the second season.. it is an incredible production.. the casting and script writing are the best you'll find today..and Jon Voight has found the high point of his career in the role of Mickey Donovan... when you see well known actors on screen, many times it's hard separating the actor from the character... not here, there's no way anyone else plays this part.. every year he should get the 'best' award.. at some point he could leave the show.. and we'll not miss the loss of another as great as we will him....this show continues on with the quality exhibited so far, it'll go down as one of the best all-time

Decided to check it out myself and I was not disappointed. Good solid story lines. Great cast. Its about time that a show of this quality is shown. I have been a captivated by the Donovans since it began and to be honest I am at loss for words at the erratic cancelation!!!! I have appreciated everything about this show and it at least deserved a proper ending!

reviews.review_title: Simply put one of the greatest shows ever aired.
reviews.content: For me personally Ray Donovan is a show that I looked forward to every year. I have to say the movie they did this year to close the characters was among the best endings to a tv series I have ever seen, leaving me perfectly satisfied, emotionally engaged the entire way through and similar to Kobe scoring 60 in his final game lets you leave everything on the table. I'd put the movie/series show ending as the second best I've seen behind True Detective season 1, and for me personally this is a top ten all-time series. Highly recommend!

reviews.review_title: Title is misleading. It should be called THE DONOVANS.
reviews.content: This is a series supposedly about a professional "fixer" for Rich and famous in L.A. Well. If that was true though then it is more than reasonable to expect that you will see some...well..."fixing"! I mean if this was supposed to be about a lawyer you obviously should expect to see some trials and a courtroom, and if the protagonist was a doctor you expect to see at least the corridors of a hospital and some people in white blouses talking about patients!Well, the premise as advertised is totally misleading.The show it's about a highly dysfunctional family where the patriarch {Mickey Donovan) is a career criminal who spend 2 decades in jail for murder. His 3-4 children (now around the age of 40) where two of them, including the titular character, were raped repeatedly by a priest. A couple of grandchildren with serious behavioral problems and their ...neurotic mother (his daughter in law).The show it should called THE DONOVANS. Much more clear and suitable title.The cast is very good. And the acting. But it's essential a family melodrama with over the top situations and you should treat it as such.The FBI is also present, but more as a caricature of itself so don't expect a police drama either. Humor or clever situations are completely absent, so don't expect it to be entertaining. Unless you think an illusion of a ...talking horse that gives you tips at the race tracks funny, so its fine by me.I should probably bash the show and give it 1 out of 10, but I watch all the episodes in its 2 seasons (with steadily diminished interest) and out of "courtesy" alone I'm giving it a 4/10.

I think Liev Schreiber is great as it is, but he plays an interesting role in Ray Donovan, and backed by an equally interesting cast. It took me until the second episode for the show to really catch me; when it did, it did big time. We often get a little glimpse of father/son relationships in certain shows, but Ray Donovan gets real gritty with that area. In fact, the whole family aspect gets a very unique spin here compared to others.So far, I'm loving this show. It's a refreshing piece of work. The acting is wonderful. Jon Voight gets to show off his acting chops (for any naysayers, they can naysay forever- Voight can act!), and of course the dynamic between him and Schreiber plays well. Eddie Marsan and Dash Mihok are enjoyable to see in the smaller roles of Ray's brothers; one with Parkinsons, the other an addict (of anything he can get his hands on). The story of the Donovan family has a lot of depth to it, and I'm excited to see where it goes as the season goes on. Ray's job, the location, Hollywood, the rich and famous; these things just add some exciting texture to it. It's so far, in my opinion, a brilliant new show. As I said before, I love Lieve Schreiber, and I hope this show will do at least reasonably well! I absolutely love it. 10 out of 10 so far.Post edit 07/14/14: I've just finished watching the Season 2 premiere, and wow- it did not disappoint. Ray Donovan just gets better and better as a show. There is already some exciting stuff about to come up and the first episode only just came on! The very last part of the first episode this season was so bad ass; even if Ray was a tough son-of-whaat, he now I am in serious awe of his toughness. Everybody should be watching this! Great cast, great writing, great characters.
Bridget ruins the series. Coulda been a 10. Bad actress. Bad role.

I really hope they come out with a new season eight but I'm hearing they are making a movie. Anyway watch the show don't wanna spoil nothing it's great. ?!!

reviews.review_title: How to ruin a perfectly good show
reviews.content: Seasons 1-2 are pretty fun dark thrillers. The formula gets a bit more of day time drama like BS in season 3-4 but remains pretty entertaining. By Season 5 it lost all of the original fun - only way to watch it is to fast forward all the melodramatic flashbacks - you can watch the season in 2-3 hours doing so and you will not loose a single thing of value from this season. Season 6 tries to track back to original ideas but I found Season 5 to be so insulting to the basic intelligence of viewers that I simply couldn't get in to it anymore.This trend the studios have to kill the formula that made a show popular with cheap drama is really getting to be obnoxious.

Very well acted. Jon Voight Is completely amazing in this role. Amazing to see him still going so strong. 
Liev Schreiber is so believable in this role, but the whole cast pulls this together.
This family's story is always rolling forward with never a dull moment.

In watching Ray Donovan, the characters have such a believable existence that you can't help but wonder about the things the rich and famous we read about daily really do. I will not be able to read about a scandal without wondering if a "cleaner" was involved. This show is a true testament to those creators and writers who have brought about something so new and fresh that all other current series seem to pale in comparison. At times, the laugh out loud tastelessness of things being said just leaves me wanting more. Even if feeling slightly guilty for laughing. I am hoping this show stays raw and powerful and witty and that we will get many more seasons of the same.

Superb episode which ties everything up.Incredible performances by all. It's an actor's movie. Jon Voight is flawless. Loved how they went back in time to reveal the truth.

This series began with a cool premise: a Hollywood fixer who cleans up after the messes of the elite. Unfortunately, they barely touch on that and instead have made it the worst kind of soup opera imaginable. I can't believe people like this. Who is the target market? I cal this dwelling on family members as the Meadow Soprano Syndrome after that series went overboard on dissecting the lives of the most uninteresting people under the sun. And who the f**k cares? It's just an excuse not to have a plot with an actual story.Ray Donovan's inner circle is made up of everything from a priest-diddled brother to another punch-drunk moron of another brother, to a loud-mouth idiot of a wife with a very phony Southie accent, to a gay kid, and an adolescent daughter that should have been put to sleep instead of forcing her on viewers. Did I miss anything? That was just the first season. I stopped after that. So if you are looking for something with almost no action but heavy on really stupid family drama then this is for you.This could have been such a cool series if they had stuck with the action. I could think of ten good stories to pursue as far as his "cleaning" business is concerned. Instead, they went telenovela.

WTF is this BS who ever wrote it this way ruined the series. i could not stand to watch most of season 5. all the flash back bs just killed it. worst idea ever. if i was watching it on live tv i would have given up on the show all together, but i was watching online so i just skipped threw most of every episode. they repeatedly flashed back to the same stuff over and over and over and over and over again. it would have gotten a 10 star rating just for season 1-4 but then i watch season 5 and couldnt do that. i would recomend just skipping season 5 all together. hopefully season 6 is better.

The only character that bothers me is Ray Donovan's spoiled brat daughter Bridget Donovan because she's a constant prude and an unappreciative snob in every episode. Almost unbearable to watch. Whoever wrote her character must be a terrible parent. That's probably the most annoying character to watch considering how super whiny she is throughout each season. I think they've could have done a much better job with casting Ray Donovan's daughter, Bridget.So many great actors and (Mickey Donovan) Jon Voight is by far my favorite character. He does an awesome job in every season and the main reason I watched the show. Overall the acting is superb and everyone does a great job with their roles. Great casting and storytelling except for Bridget Donovan. The art directions pretty impressive as well as the scouted locations. Once you start the first season you'll be hooked I want to binge watch the rest of the seasons. I'm looking forward to more seasons in the future including the eighth and hopefully a lot more.

Ray Donovan has some of the best character development I've ever seen on a show. As I watched it I had to keep reminding myself it was all fiction. I've seen a few complaints about season five. I agree, they didn't need to kill the main female character. However, I found that season to be the most relatable season of the entire show. My spouse died of cancer at a young age. I felt very much the same as Ray's character. It is more than devastating when something like this happens. It was so relatable that I had a difficult time watching the season. The show took such a dark turn from season five and in the following seasons. And although I found it relatable, I was not happy they killed off one of the best characters. She was the woman who held Ray and the family together. The actress playing Abby did an astounding job her entire run on the show.Someone commented that the cancer experience was inaccurate and unrealistic. This person clearly needs the subtitles and also doesn't understand that every cancer experience is different. They claimed that Abby said she was going to "start" treatment when she was already losing hair. She didn't say "start," she said "stop treatment." So it was accurate she had lost her hair at that point. What Abby went through on the show was similar to what my spouse went through. Of course real cancer is worse in real life than when on tv. It's not like the actors can go catch some cancer so that the play the part realistically enough. I wish I could comment on other people's reviews, because some comments really annoyed me.I also read a handful of negative reviews on the actress who played Brigit. I'm shocked some people find it necessary to insult her appearance. She is a cute girl who played her role well. Makes me wonder what some of these fools look like in real life themselves.With all that said, Ray Donovan is and always will be one of the best shows. I was really disappointed when they didn't renew it. At least they could've given it a proper last season. I recently rewatched the show to prepare for the movie. Hopefully the movie gives us fans some closure. These characters and their stories deserved better than being suddenly canceled.

Never have I seen a bigger bunch of whiners and n'er do wells that blamed everything they ever did on their childhoods and, in particular, their father. GROW UP! The four boys, Ray, Terry, Daryll and Bunchy (Liev Schreiber, Eddie Marian, Pooch Hall and Dash Mihok) blame everything bad in their lives on their father, Mickey (Jon Voight), and Ray's kids, Bridget and Conor (Kerris Dorsey and Devon Bagby) blame everything bad in their lives on Ray. That's a very convenient philosophy: Everything good in your life you accomplished and everything bad is your father's fault. The only two characters who take responsibility for their own lives, and as such, are the two strongest regular characters in the series are the aforementioned Mickey and Ray's wife, Abby (Paula Malcomson). That said, I love 'Ray Donovan.' It is a unique concept, featuring top notch writing and situational humor. Jon Voight literally steals the show in a role he was meant to play. Liev Schreiber is the star and the catalyst around which the show is based, so if he he was weak, so too would be the show. Paula Malcomson is also a standout. Mickey's boys are all excellent. I enjoyed Ray's son, Devon Bagby, but Kerris Dorsey always annoyed me. A host of notable guest stars were stellar, including: James Woods, Elliot Gould, Steven Bauer, Susan Sarandon, Peter Gerety, Austin Nichols, Frank Whaley, Brian Geraghty, Ian McShane, Hank Azaria, Sandy Martin and Alan Alda. Special mention to Katharine Moening for her recurring role as Ray's faithful sidekick, Lena and Graham Rogers (Smitty) from whom I expect big things. The move to NYC, in Season 6, gave the series a shot in the arm as it created a new look and feel and new story lines, but we had an almost comatose Ray who kept getting his ass kicked. A huge booo! To Showtime for summarily canceling the show after Season 7, even though they had already committed to a Season 8. Like HBO's entirely premature canceling of 'Deadwood', Showtime saw the error of its ways and commissioned a, yet unreleased, 2 hour film in order to give this highly-worthy series a proper resolution and send off. I look forward to seeing that ending and I will miss this very original series.

reviews.review_title: Catchy, with Season 2 more versatile and dynamic than 1
reviews.content: Ray Donovan (perhaps with not the best choice of title) is another fine example of recent trend when crime series have become more interesting and meatier than crime movies. Lots of acclaimed actors, intertwining characters and events, and twisted twists make such series interesting to follow - but, for the sake of full comprehension, you should have time and opportunity to watch all episodes in succession. All this applies to the series in question, where the cast is evenly strong (well, Jon Voight as Mickey Donovan and Liev Schreiber as Raymond "Ray" Donovan stick out still), and the situations and relations get complicated a lot, without becoming airy-fairy, and the nature of Ray's duties and his big family enable to deal with dozens of different mini-scenes. Perhaps too much for some, but I personally liked to follow what happened in different places at the same time. Moreover, in many situations, I could ponder on and over complex issues, how/if I could resolve such a situation, and have some sympathy with characters even when the situation was unpleasant or even rude...Good job, and I am looking for the next season already.

I loved the first show so much i decided to keep Showtime after my free trial. By Season 3 i regret it. In the middle of season 3 Abby says the 'f' word each time she speaks and many of the other characters do also. I measure of show by the necessity of putting the 'f' word in the writing as a contrived filler. As in life, the more the 'f' or 'c' words are used the more of an illiterate , ignorant low life a person is. I love vulgarity but it's not power packed unless used rarely and wisely. I wish Mickey would have been killed of long ago because he's boring. All the brothers but Ray are dunces by Season 3. They all say they hate Mickey and say they'll stay away from him yet they let Mickey step on them episode after samo samo episode showing what masochists they all are. Abby started out hot, strong and cool and now she's a trite foul mouthed weakling. Stale is the word to describe the series now. Not even someone with good ADHD, like me, can be sucked in anymore. There are always, at least, 5 soap opera plots going on with these fine actors having sloppy writing and poor plots to burden themselves with. Even Ray's looks and overly nonchalant behavior get weary. Mickey is simply irritating and , mostly , the whole darn show lacks credibility. But, since i'm stuck with the subscription for a month i'll trudge my way through it. reviews.review_title: Tough guy Dad kicks bad guy ass to protect family; typical vigilante crap
reviews.content: There is nothing new here. The main character is the same vigilante you have seen many times before (The Shield, anyone?) he is a total bad ass that kicks the crap out of anyone he wants too like an MMA pro. The plots are all the same-"Bad guy mistreats women or children, bad guy gets beaten to a pulp or killed". There is NO suspense.It is a blue collar family with big time white collar money. They live in a mansion in Calabasses and never seem to have any financial troubles. Although they do fake "southie" accents and sound, well, not real "smaht", they live like the 1 percent. I think they wanted your average families to relate, but they over did it with the bad grammar.The main character Ray is a Stoic martyr who's only sin is cheating on his wife occasionally, but he doesn't seem to enjoy it. There are evil Russians, evil Mexicans, evil cops; Ray is pretty evil too but anytime he say, murders somebody if they were a risk to his kids, well then that's OK. His kids can do whatever they want by the way- stalk their teachers, shoot guns into neighbors homes, do drugs whatever; they will still be showered with money as some sort of birth right. I wonder - who is paying for all this?Movie makers have been giving us this stuff for years. I wonder if America has become so paranoid, selfish and obsessive about their kids because of this. We see a patriarch beat a guy to death for making an offensive joke within ear shot of his wife or kids, and then think we have to cocoon ourselves in a gated community , get a gun, and shoot any adult male who looks suspicious. In real life the real Ray Donovan went to jail; the writers of this were too chicken to portray this .

Although I gave it a 9 there are some episodes that are a 10. I'm not saying that you are all going to agree with me, each character is dealing with terrible and emotional moments recreated by these actors bringing the emotion alive and done beautifully. Not to say at times this series is brutal, a sad testament to our times, but it is acted brilliantly, believable, this incredible group of actors who make this show what it is, dealing with some of the most difficult moments in their character's lives and the fall-out of those horrendous moments. If these things were to happen to anyone you know or to you, how would you deal with it? How could you cope knowing that your childhood was hijacked and you didn't know any better. After all counselors were unheard of during parts of the fifties and sixties, if you had a problem you went to your priest or pastor.....that these characters are carrying on to the best of their ability and making it believable makes this one of the greatest series on cable.

"Ray Donovan" is basically a drama series about a complicated crime family that could be described as a worthy successor to "The Sopranos", but it is much more. It centres on a morally ambiguous Ray, who is a Hollywood fixer, but it has many complex layers that include his immediate family and friends. Ray's father is played by Jon Voight and it is a real treat to see him back on the screen in such great form. Paula Malcomson is perfectly cast as Ray's long-suffering wife, Abby.Liev Schreiber has found possibly the role of his career. He is Raymond Donovan both in mind and body. Once you start watching an episode, nothing will drag you away. It is one of the few TV series that makes you yearn for the next episode. That it has incredible actors, great stories and stunning photography is a given but the sheer complexity of all the characters makes every episode special viewing and I hope it has a very long and successful run.

There is a lot to like about Ray Donovan. The acting is good; the production values are excellent; it's a well-shot show; and the writing is also pretty good. There is one major problem, however. It's with the set-up. There is a fatal problem with the narrative story. It doesn't make sense.Critical to the success of the show is Ray's relationship with his father (played by Jon Voight). The way that Voight's character is written suggests that he is to be feared, that he is a loose cannon, that his relationship with Ray was so dark and black and unforgivable that reconciliation could never be thought possible. And the success of the show depends upon that.Instead, while we wait and wait and wait and wait for some grand revelation that could make sense of the backbone of the entire narrative of Ray Donovan, it never comes. Sure, there are things that are revealed. The nonsense about the father being set-up and going to jail for twenty years for something that he didn't do was ridiculous. What was Ezra's involvement? Never disclosed. Ray has legitimate beefs with his father, but it never rises to the level that would support the antagonism that is necessary for the conflict in the story to take root. It, thus, becomes academic, and in the end, unsatisfying. Moreover, it would seem to me that the father would be angrier and more resentful towards Ray for being set-up and sent away for much of his adult life. The father is no saint, that is for sure, but he is no demon and no mafia kingpin. Why is he feared? Why is Ray afraid of his influence on his children? Perhaps had the father been the one who molested Bunchy -- instead of a priest -- that would have made it more compelling . . . a rehabilitated pedophile? Maybe that would be a hard sell, but a former drug seller and embezzler just didn't cut it as a man someone like Ray Donovan would fear, let alone want dead. Without there being a strong narrative structure, the story simply doesn't fly. It is reduced to a man (Ray Donovan) who has an irrational fear of his father and will stop at nothing to shut him down. Ultimately, the father ends up simply being a flawed person who has in many respects failed his family in the past. But a terrible person? A monster? A man to be feared? All he wants -- and all he ever wanted for the entire season -- is to be close to his family after he gets out of jail.What can I say? It was largely a waste of twelve hours.I won't be watching subsequent seasons, and I do not recommend.

I did watch EVERY episode so I am being fair to this show. This show borrowed a LOT from other concepts, which well, is not a bad thing in itself. People pointed out it borrowed the crime boss/family guy concept from the Sopranos, Irish mobsters from every Boston crime movies, starting with the Departed with a Whitey Bulger clone, Sully played by James Wood thrown in. So close to real life this one was that he hid out in Santa Monica too. But it also had Beverly Hillbillies concept where uncouth South Boston Irish descend on trendy, modern LA and rub shoulders with the degenerate rich and famous. But unlike Jed and his clan, who are decent honest people, this clan is mainly a bunch of punks and killers, with some sad sack brothers for pathos and comedy relief thrown in. At first I thought Ray would just pull slightly sleazy maneuvers to get his star clients off the hook; like switching out the man in a dead coke whore's hotel room from a black athlete to a bisexual action movie star who was being outed as gay right before his latest action movie came out. But like Dexter, Ray seems to have a special license to kill or seriously injure rivals since they are bad people too. He beat a peeping tom to death when he simply could have had him arrested for say child porn since he and his crew of operators seem to be experts at all sorts of dirty tricks. But since the guy was a perv, it was okay to kill him in order to protect his blond air head child star girlfriend.There is also his two messed up brothers, one who is a church abuse rape victim, Bunchy, who hangs at the boxing gym run by his other brother, who is a crude but somewhat honorable boxer with Parkinsons, Terry. Bunchy seemed to be channeling Tim Robbins from Mystic River with a man- boy victim act gone viral. He is supposed to be some alky in recovery, but always ends up drinking, you get it. Then there is a black half brother who Ray finds out about in the opening of the show, Darryl, Of course, he hangs out in the gym and drinks and fights with the rest of the boys. Finally, his dad Mickey, played by Jon Voight, seems to steal every scene he is in with his hammed up old jailbird low level mob act. You see, Ray and his going senile boss Ezra, aka Eliot Gould, started this star protection business by framing Mickey for the murder of Ray's old girlfriend. Mickey did 20 years for a murder that the firm's first star customer committed. but since the star was high on Mickey's drugs and used Mickey's gun, Ray felt it was okay to stick it to his dad. You see, his dad turned away when Ray and Bunchy were being abused by the priest. The church sex abuse scandal is also featured prominently in this show, and it is not very friendly to the Church, if that bothers you. As a matter of fact, the opening scene of the show where Mickey got released from Walpole Penitentiary. On the ride home, Mickey goes and shoots a priest dead with a gun stuck in his mouth that he thought molested his kids.Then there is Rays own wife and kids, including the grating ginger wife Abby and two well groomed kids. Ray of course keeps them so in the dark that in the case when they actually might be in danger, Ray doesn't actually warn them but sends his ex Mossad sidekick Avi. Avi, played by Steven Bauer, is actually the most interesting of all the characters, since he doesn't seem to have any sort of attitude, unlike everyone else who has a 100 lbs chip on their shoulder. Okay, the show has lots of characters and actors who are way more interesting than laconic macho Ray, aka Liev Schreiber. As an actor, Liev is at best a co-star, He is just too wooden to be taken very seriously. As well as his character, no matter how hard they ham up the family protector angle, is just too amoral and criminal to be respected. He is just a greedy sadist who hides behind his family, like where he tortured a sleazy (aren't they all?) real estate agent to get ALL his stupid brother's money back, even after his demented brother torched one of the rooms in a drunken fit. Jeez Ray, toss the guy say 10g for his pain! A good chunk of the show revolves around how Ray, after his dad did 20 years in place of a star criminal that Ray helped cover for, decides to have his dad murdered. And who does Ray get to kill his dad? The mass murdering psycho mobster Bulger clone Sully who wastes about a dozen other people instead after Ray drags him out to the west coast. The show has a Dexter angle, (another SHO production) where if you stick to killing bad guys and are nice to women and kids, you get a pass. But Dexter was a lot tighter a show and took longer to wear itself out unlike this three ring circus of freaks, plastic people and punks.

Ray Donovan and the first minutes of season 1, episode 1 will be the horror historians point to when they describe the unrecoverable collapse of civilization. It's as if the showrunner was attempting to win the following bet: "How repulsive can you make yourself, and keep your job?"

reviews.review_title: One of the best character written shows on TV
reviews.content: I caught this show through a suggestion by a friend who actually lives in England. Since I live in LA and he was surprised I had not watched it. I am not really a big fan of LA shows, especially when its focused on the Hollywood celebrities and their problems. However, from the first episode I was really impressed that this show's writers had a different take about a guy like Ray Donovan "The Fixer" who goes around and intercepts through any bully tactics, to solve situations and problems of the Hollywood elite and their dirty laundry; yet he is very internally conflicted in his own personal life with the people he loves. To my own surprise for some reason I got really hooked into this show from the first episode. Maybe partially because it does not portray Ray as a nice guy, in fact he is as bad as as any criminal, he has all the right people in his pocket that owe him favor or he something on them to black mail them to fix a problem. In one hour this show shuffles through so many characters that you feel the hour is filled with great characters, great acting one scene after another. It also does not feel like it's based in LA, more like an East coast, because LA is not a place where you associate a Boxing gym and a bunch of tough Irish guys hanging out, that's why this shows fails to City's landmarks and streets in general, it's the weakest part compare to a show like "Southland" that really shows LA as it is. Ray Donovan is always at the center of this show, but his father and brothers each get a equal time with their personal issues too. Ray's wife Abbey played by "Paula Malcomson" who I think its best in the show, there is so much in just her expressions and eyes without any words. I think its character like Ray's brother "Bunchy" who have been damaged by some childhood trauma and still struggling with, its what makes this show so rich in writing. Ray himself is a very angry and damaged person whose brooding face is almost a permanent mask he wears to the outside world as a shield. Ray's work is as immoral and illegal as any criminal, he really reminds me of another "Tony Soparono". This show somehow does parallel in some part to "The Sopranos", the scenes with Abbey and Ray remind a little of Tony and Carmela at times, but it goes further deeper into their relationship, Abbey is more aware of Ray's lies, even though she tolerates his infidelity, but she demands emotional honesty from Ray, which is not something Ray is capable of even to himself; at least even Tony Soprano went to therapy to get some help but Ray's only solution is the bottle and the rage he carries inside,his resentments against his father that he wants to have killed, anger his fuel. I was never fan of "Sopranos", I only liked the late "James Gandolfini" whose acting was the center of that show, there was no Sopranos without him been in it and what it became. "The Sopranos" was not really about anything than bunch of gangsters; the therapy sessions in the first two seasons were at the heart of it but that lost focus after the 3rd season, then it became a TV version of "Good fellas"; with almost half of the same cast.This show however "Ray Donovan", has something called depth and intelligence, its written with heart; its characters are troubled like "Terry', Ray's other brother who runs the Boxing gym, his right hand has twitch and broken heart tattood on his chest, their father Micky, play by the legendary "Jon Voight" whom has not done anything like this good for a long time, he plays an ex-con who is really hard to get a read on at times, he is both good and bad like Ray; that's why they mirror each other and their conflict with one another is confused and unexplained. That is mostly to Ray's hatred and holding on to his own perception of the past. It even puts some focus on Ray's kids, they are not used as props and their issues at home and growing up is part of Ray's struggles to center him in a way, his family is his refuge but even with them he hides who he really is. I read a lot of great reviews here on this show how it was compared to same level of writing and depth of shows like "Dexter" and "Breaking Bad"; which are both superb shows too but I still think this show will probably surpass both those two shows in years to come, it can easily go 5 to 8 seasons. Although "Breaking Bad" had a central character "Walter White", the show's whole theme is about the change of this ordinary chemistry teacher to this mean ruthless meth dealer, how good changes to evil, the other supporting cast like his wife had no real change or issues as the range of multiple characters on "Ray Donovan", where each character has their personal conflict, this is truly one of the best shows on Cable TV today and I hope they stay on the air.

SPOILERS!!!!!!
The writers of this show, though creative, have forgotten to tie up the ends on so many issues that it gets very annoying. Do they think that those who watch the show forget what's happened? Maybe it's because I'm streaming the shows, but I find it very annoying. Bungy's settlement money just stopped being mentioned, though he knew who had it, and he was going to get it. Dropped! Ray gave Bungy the bar but, when they all move to NY, no mention of the bar which was supposed to support Bungy and his family. It just evaporated, along with any mention of what the bar was worth. Again, leaving Bungy with nothing! The ransom money, stolen by Mick's sister-in-law? We see her driving away, while drinking and not watching the road. Did she crash, and the 3 million burn up? Never mentioned again. They sold their home in California, but when Ray is in NY, he is homeless, living with the cop who rescued him. Etc. etc. etc. How about tying up ends? Crazy gaps everywhere! More continuity would be greatly appreciated by those of us who actually watch the show!

At first I was skeptic, after seeing series like The Sopranos, Breaking Bad and Boardwalk Empire my expectations to a new TV show were sky-high.The first look at the cast of this show made me curious, I mean a series with Liev Schreiber, Steven Bauer, Elliott Gould and Jon Voight really sounds good in the first place.After seeing the first 3 episodes I already knew I'm gonna love it and I wasn't disappointed after I finished the last episode of the first season.Liev Schreiber's acting in this show is top-notch, and I have to admit I have never been a big fan of him before, but this show made up his reputation to me, he definitely has what it takes to play a leading character. But the one who really stands out is Jon Voight. He is definitely at the top of his game in this show and I was really surprised by his emotional bandwidth.The show has all ingredients to become a cult classic, it has great cinematography, great acting and writing and the score really caught my attention.

If you enjoy subtly, watch this show. If you need things spelt out for you, step-by-step, explicitly with poor writing, don't watch this show. If you like character-driven drama with quality acting, watch this show. If you have a short attention span and need action sequences every second minute to avoid channel surfing to the next thing, don't watch this show.Ray Donovan is a well-written, superbly-acted, character-driven drama. After two episodes, it is clear that Liev Schreiber and Jon Voight have bought in fully to their roles and they are nailing them. Supporting performances are also very strong, in my opinion.I expect plenty of people to be confused by the plot, because the writers don't feel the need to spoon-feed the audience. You have to pay attention and not everyone has that ability. In my opinion, this is everything a quality TV Show should be, when it is written, directed, and produced for an intelligent audience.
If the extraordinary acting of this ensemble doesn't win an Emmy, there's something wrong somewhere! Season 6 is unbelievably fantastic! Well done you guys 👍👍👍

reviews.review_title: Hoped it would be good - WRONG
reviews.content: OK, so it's a jumbled mess, far too convoluted and confusing to even try to take it seriously. But worse, it's mean-spirited. Nastiness in about every-other scene. No, make that two out of three scenes.I'd hoped it would show us the talents of Liev Schreiber to advantage, and that he would carry the show along in an entertaining way. Instead he's a closed-mouth, terse, laconic character who is about as frozen as a Popsicle. He's a great actor, but in this show the director reins him in so tightly that his prodigious talents are wasted.They surround him with a huge ensemble cast, the result being that we get about one total minute of this guy, two total minutes of that guy (chopped up in pieces throughout), and Elliott Gould mumbling Yiddish and stumbling around fully clothed in the surf. OY!Wanting a good new series to watch, I pinned my hopes on Ray Donovan. I might better have pinned a tail on a donkey. It would have been more fun.

reviews.review_title: It's too bad that no other actor could share the scene with Jon Voigt's stellar performance
reviews.content: This is a series that should have called it quits after the first four (4) seasons. That is about all the number of predictable episodes that I could stomach of the brooding Ray Donovan (Liev Schreiber) and his bitter and angry wife Abby (Paula Malcomson).Jon Voigt's character, Mickey Donovan, Ray's hip and slick talking career criminal father and lover of the black booty, was amazing. If it wasn't for Jon Voigt's stellar performance I would have stopped watching it long before the series ended after seven (7) long and grueling seasons.By season 5 the series just dragged on from bad to worse and the entire Donovan families In-fighting became so predictable that Mrs. Shullivan and I kept falling asleep during certain episodes and neither one of us suggested "re-winding" because we could accurately predict what had happened. A fight broke out, blood was spilled, another family argument, and then on to the next predictable episode.I give the series a 9 out of 10 for the first four (4) seasons and then it drops to a 3 out of 10 for seasons five (5) through seven (7) averaging out to a mediocre 6 out of 10 IMDb rating.

reviews.review_title: This show is incredibly well done
reviews.content: Screenplay, dialogue, acting, charachter development, cinematography, direction, lighting, soundtrack... It's all on point.If you're squirmy there are some scenes where you'll want to avert your eyes, not too many though, it's not gratuitously violent by any means.Each charachters personal story is well developed and surprisingly relatable.This is a phenomenal crima/drama/thriller. I highly suggest you watch it. I'd rank it up there with Season one of True Detective.Watch it.

Addictive wild fun all the way through and thought provoking! In the last year I got entirely caught up that was so enjoyable and a lot of unexpected crime suspense along with great build up. I absolutely love the cast, soundtrack, writing, and subtlety simple conversations! The madness the Donavan's deal with throughout is riveting - Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: Please renew for at least one more season...
reviews.content: Season 7 finale was not a proper series finale. Now that Ray finally found out what really happened to his sister, there has to be more reaction from the rest of the family. I've watched this show from day one and if the studio wants to cancel this show, then do it with a bang for the loyalty of your fans!!!

reviews.review_title: Just can't get enough of this programme
reviews.content: Very seldom do I write a review. Even less often do I find myself watching a TV show and then feeling unable to tear myself away before I watch the next one.What stands this show apart from others, is the way the writers stick to the story. The characters evolve, always in a way you cannot predict, but yet realise afterwards, it couldn't have gone any other way. No one is particularly likable, and when you first start watching it, you feel slightly angry with yourself for committing to it. You may even question what you like about it, when everything that happens in it is so dark, gritty and grim.But the acting is phenomenal, and each character develops in a way that is almost genius. Each character has their own pull. Sometimes when you watch a show there are certain scenes that you can't be bothered with because you don't care about that particular character as much as others. In Ray Donovan ALL of the characters are compelling and unique. Even the vulgar and hateful Mickey is just too awful for words BUT absolutely brilliant in every way.Bridget, and Abby are both fantastic in their roles. And now in season 3 the newly introduced Finneys are amazing creations, taking the show down a whole new journey.This is a highly underrated programme, and one of my favourite all time things I've ever watched. Almost want to stop watching it, so I can savour my last few episodes before I begin season 4.

reviews.review_title: A grittier Entourage without the cameos
reviews.content: I have not seen any advertisements of this series like other reviewers, but after watching the pilot episode I have to say this is the best new original series i have watched this year besides Hannibal. It takes a lot of familiar plot elements from its cable TV predecessors, and adds more to it. It's not as dark and monotonous like Homeland, but still brings the necessary suspense to it that makes this highly original series more of a dark comedy than a serial drama Jon Voight and Liev Schriber are excellent as the main roles in this series. I hope the writers can build on this interesting premise, and make it a hit TV series that it deserves to be. 8 out of 10

reviews.review_title: So many superlatives, brilliant, outstanding, superb, absolutely amazing
reviews.content: The characters, the storyline, the chaos, the twists and turns, the sheer brilliance of just about everything about this show. I started out watching this, knowing there was 7 seasons and nearly 100 episodes but even before the end of s1, I was already thinking about what a vacuum there would be once this ends, how will I find something better than this? And how would this find its way into my top 5 top 10 box sets, well it not only did that, it smashed others out of the way. This competes on the same level as Sopranos! Pure binge heaven. A true masterstroke by the writers, creators and directors. They definitely took note of shows like Sopranos as there are some subliminal similarities the further you go. Outstanding

Liev Schreiber is Ray Donavon & Ray Donavon is Liev Schreiber.
This show would not be what it is if it wasn't for Liev and a great cast. The whole Donavon family has their own dark paths throughout the whole show.
Jon Voight's character Mickey Donavon is one of the best characters on TV, past and present.
With twists & turns all the way through the show, Ray Donavon is gripping, dark and heart warming...all rolled in to one fantastic show.Would of give it 10/10 is the show wasn't suddenly cancelled for no reason!
I just finished Season 1 and I kind of like it I will continue to watch season 2
I've always thought highly of this show, but Season 6 brings it to a level of greatness I just wasn't expecting. Terrific, just plain terrific.

Man, has this show gone down hill!Up to last season, the majority of which was as dull drab and boring as possibly can be, this was a really cool show to look forward to every week. Fast forward to 2019, now it feels tedious watching this constant self loathing, self pity, self sabotaging, poor me, I'll do anything to destroy my family - crap. Where is the cool, clever, loyal, bad Ray Donovan we all fell in love with?!!!Come on Showtime.. this and all of these new down dumbing desensitizing garbage sex-related PC political "docu" shows youre putting out are enough to cancel my subscription.What once was a solid 9 star show is now at best a 5. Grrrrr

Ray Donovan was a great series. I don't understand why it was cancelled except that maybe some thought Ray was too much of a "toxic" male. It was also somewhat disparaging of the Catholic church, so maybe that had something to do with it. But the characters were great and the acting was superb. To end the series with a two-hour movie did not do it justice. I did not think Ray's character was an "over-the-top" tough guy ala John Wick. It had plenty of tough-guy elements (I mean we're talking about Irish mobsters), but there were also elements of family drama and Ray juggling his life as a fixer, while trying to manage his family problems. There were some seasons where I felt like the writers made incongruent changes to the story line from one season to the next, but overall the story lines remained lineal and in-tune with audience expectations.

I tried several times to watch this but just kept losing interest. The concept of a shady fixer for celebrities is great. Then it seems to be ditched and replaced with some sort of family drama. I am not sure who the audience is. There are many positive reviews so it must please someone

I wanted to like this show, but season after season, nothing has changed. I keep reading in the reviews about great character development, but to me the characters haven't changed and more importantly I can care less about any one of them. Every time it seems like maybe someone has an opportunity to turn a corner and move forward with their life, they just revert back to the same stereotypical character that they have been portraying throughout the series. For those who feel differently, enjoy, but for me, I'm done.

reviews.review_title: An addictive, outstanding and important show
reviews.content: The more I watch this, the more I like it. I have watched each year since it began and it continues to amaze me. I am of Irish heritage so my initial interest was related to how they would weave in our cultural issues with crime and punishment. The early years did so with, among other things, story elements that included deeply disturbing problems in the Catholic Church. But this now goes way beyond this as it factors in our present day corruption in many other realms of life. And the acting? Each and every actor should get an Emmy! Really. I predict that like "The Wire" this will be a show long valued, remembered and watched.

reviews.review_title: Mickey " D " steals the show.... but others good too
reviews.content:
I always knew John Voight was a good actor. Ever since his role in Midnight Cowboy and the in " Deliverance ".But Geez, in his role as Micky Donavan.... I have a newfound respect for this astoundingly great actor.I must say, Othersin the cast are stellar as well.... but JOHN Voight shows why he is an academy awarded winner - and 4 tine nominee.He nails the " Boston " accent perfectly as well.The storyline is so freakin good . The acting is staggeringly good.Don't miss this gem
If a show!

Before Season 5, this series was okay to watch and kept me interested week after week, but season 5 is not good, just like 'True Detective" or the pathetic "Tin Star", I think Season 5 has lost it. It spent too much time in retrospection, too much and too many flashbacks that Ray lost in trance to his dead wife, Abby. The story suffered a serious setback from Episode 1, and the downward decline just couldn't stop to Episode 7. Like Ray Donovan's tired face, this series also making me feel tired to the bone.Furthermore, the girl who plays Ray's daughter seems to became even uglier after 4 Seasons, her whole facial structure just fell out with overly protruding cheekbones, lower chin and caved-in nose and mouth areas that made me feel very uncomfortable every time when she appeared on screen. When there's a dialog by some players in this series praised her beautiful face, it just made me want to puke.Again, I just wish Ray won't spend his next episode to force us watching him to lost himself in remembering his dead wife. Enough is enough, you stupid producers and screenplay writers. I like the character, Avi, very much, and hate to see him needs to disappear, because the only face that I wish to disappear is Ray's daughter.
Came back to this show to finish it off and Season 6 is freaking incredible. One of the best seasons of ANY series. Stellar stellar season.

I've been watching this entire first season and all I can think is that I hope they just cancel this stupid show. It's over hyped and stupid. Not to mention I think it's over dramatic and senseless. This is the first time I really hated a John Voight character. Too much overacting and none of the characters mesh well. Please just replace this show with something else. The wife's accent is really fake an annoying, the kid that lives next door is horrible. His brothers provide no real story line and Ray is exactly what you expect. No surprises. I don't know how so many people gave this show a great review so quickly but it isn't worth your time.

reviews.review_title: Started on top of a mountain but finished at the bottom of a ditch
reviews.content: The first 2 series were original and a gripping drama which seemed to be heading toward great TV. 3-4 was the beginning of the cracks to show but still watchable and had its moments but by series 5 you may ask well throw in the towel and save yourself from the utter drivel from Ray Donovan the one man mafia who has more lives then 10 cats put together.

I started binge-watching this show on a rainy weekend, just looking for something new to get into. Given the general premise, the fact that it starred Liev & Jon and the favorable rating on IMDB I figured it would be right up my alley.Well, I made it into season 2 before finally throwing in the towel, I just became indifferent, bored, and it became cringeworthy and bothersome. I think if I started watching this weekly back when it aired instead of bingeing, I would have given up on it much sooner. But I wanted to give it a fair shot hoping it would get better.Ultimately what lead to me giving it up was a combination of the believability factor, coupled with characters I just couldn't get into. Starting with the believability factor, I get it, this is TV, not real life, it's for entertainment, etc.... But the show does take itself serious and even know one must suspend disbelief for certain things, it was just too far off the grid for me. It wasn't the action which surprisingly seemed believable, but rather relationship dynamics, and how people would typically interact and react to things, especially between Ray and his wife & kids. No way is any of this remotely close to real life. As far as all Ray's work-related dealings, that part of the show I actually liked, but going back to the believability factor, it was just too far away from reality for me to roll with.Now onto the characters, this was the other thing that ultimately bounced me out of the show. For a show to remain intriguing enough to keep one's interest, you have to be able to like or relate to some of the characters, it gives you something to root for and invest into. However, for this to work characters at least have to remain somewhat consistent or be grounded to whatever principles they adhere to. In this show the two main characters Ray & Mickey would act a certain way, and then go do something so conflicting or polar opposite that it just creates an artificial or unnatural chaos. And for the record I'm totally fine with morally gray characters, but they at least have to be somewhat consistent, unless they are a psychopath or something. In this case I couldn't care or get invested into Ray, his father, or pretty much anyone else from his family. About the only characters I liked were Terry, Avi & Lena, but collectively they have such low screen time that it didn't amount to muchTo sum up, I like the main plot theme, and a few of the supporting characters, but for me it fell flat with characters actions or interactions, and lack of consequences for anything, just so outside of the normal world. I found myself spending more time questioning: "How could that person just do that", "why would that person just put up with that", "how can that person be such a rich powerful person and yet such an idiot", or "How is it that people can just down glasses of hard alcohol in pretty much every scene like it's water, not show any stick faces, and not seem to get drunk." Anyway enough is enough for me...
Love this show. Live Schreiber is superb, John Voight even better. Gritty, dark and funny, drama at its very best. Brilliant.

reviews.review_title: Awful characters - the men are horrible and the women are pathetic
reviews.content: I've watched the first episode, I will not watch anymore. It made me so angry. The men are violent and horrible and the women are pathetic. There is one female character who is strong and independent, but guess what? She's a lesbian! According to this men can get away with doing whatever they want and women are there to be used / manipulated / protected because they are too weak to do anything else.I struggle to see why anyone can enjoy this, nasty people getting away with doing nasty things because they have money and fame. There were one or two good lines but not enough to justify how horrible the rest of the program was. I'm not a prude, but there needs to be some relief or a reason for the sex / violence / discrimination in there somewhere.

reviews.review_title: Not the best TV, but not the worst
reviews.content: As others have suggested, this seem like an interesting idea for a show, but it is really poorly executed. I've now watched the first four episodes, and the pilot was easily the worst, and the others have gotten a bit better. But the writing and directing are really not very good. I don't really care about any of these characters, and find myself reaching for the fast forward button to get past long brooding moments, and painfully bad dialogue. And I like many of the actors in show, but writing has ruined it.Now many people who rate shows at IMDb seem to think there are only two possible ratings, 1 and 10. I rate Ray Donavan as a 5 and I hope it is going to improve as the season continues, regrettably it doesn't seem to be improving very much so far..

While the writing is good and the actors are overall, very good, there are a few grating inconsistencies from time to time. I'm rewatching season 6 and there are some pretty intrusive problems that are more noticeable on a second viewing.In a fight scene with Terry, his tattoos get rubbed away, not just a little smearing, but actually bare spots in a couple of the tats. The writing, while good overall, leaves one bad plot hole: Bunch gets Sandy's keys to go and get some paperwork, and when he comes back, Sandy has taken all of Mick's money and has left. She is shown driving her car to Boston....the car that Bunch borrowed and which couldn't have been there for her to take.Not too bad, I suppose, but the scenes in bars always shows a bartender taking a cap off of a bottle and pouring a drink. Bartenders use pour spouts on bottles, and have since the '50s. It's pretty hard to keep up with serving drinks if you have to uncap and recap bottles for each drink.So, the writers, directors and continuity people do drop the ball here and there. It's still a good series.

reviews.review_title: What the hell has happened to Ray Donovan?
reviews.content: *****SPOILERS*****I loved this show. The first 4 seasons were some of the best tv available. I should say, 3 1/3 seasons.Abby's sickness and death did more than mark the, (unnecessary), departure of a good character, but it pretty much killed off what made the show great.Whatever happened, though highs and lows, Ray was always strong. He bounced back. He managed to hold everybody together. Since moving the show east, Ray has been a sad, inconsequential shadow of his former self. Instead of the extraordinary fixer, fighting through his sadness at the loss of his wife, he has devolved into a two bit hood that anybody can kick around.Ray Donovan has become a chump. W.T.F? There were glimmers of the former Ray here and there but holy crap, this is getting hard to sit through. He's turned into ol' yeller...basically waiting for a bullet, and it's not entertaining to watch.He now sucks as a fixer. His family, (that he did so many terrible things to support), either uses him and/or has abandoned him. His few friends screw him over. He was always a drunk, but now he's a drunken loser...and as of the last episode I saw, he wakes up in a psycho ward.Micky was entertaining but now he's just annoying. Bunchy has gone from useless to pathetic. Terry started fighting again...for absolutely no reason. We knew that he would after Ray warned him that his parkinson's would come back...and voila...his parkinson's is back. Not so subtle, that foreshadowing.Lena is momentarily happy with a girlfriend...but we can't have that, so they kill off the girlfriend. Both of his kids hate his guts.Wow. How the mighty have fallen. The show was always dark, but now it's bleak. They turned Ray into a sad pu$$y. I know the season is already filmed but I sure hope they can pump some life into this thing in the editing room.I have tried to but I don't feel I have properly expressed my disappointment with the developments of Ray Donovan. If feels like everybody just stopped trying. Mediocre, cliche writing. Dead eyed, wooden acting. If they were trying for gravitas, they shot way past the mark and are currently falling through catatonic.Maybe they shouldn't have pulled Ray out of the water. At least then we would mostly have good memories of the show.Sure...I'll probably watch the rest of the season. I probably have another 4 hours of my life I can spare but it's more out of curiosity over how much more depressing they can make this once amazing show, than out of any hope of that they can pull out of the tailspin.

reviews.review_title: First 4 seasons are great, but then it crashes
reviews.content: I loved the first 4 seasons, but not a fan of season 5. Stupid plot decision, and it consumed the entire season. Plus the ongoing flashback thing sucked. Season 6 and the move to New York might be even worse, as Ray stumbles around in a stupor. Most of the characters are great, with Jon Voight stealing the show, but both of "Ray's kids" end up sucking and are horribly annoying. Still, the first 4 seasons are so good, I'll give it an 8 out of 10. Hoping they somehow get a chance to do season 8. Maybe they can end it on a high note.

If you watched the Sopranos and liked it you will like this. The acting was good, the camera work was good and most of the plots were believable. My complaints were with Abby and her horrible attempts at an accent. It was like she couldn't decide which she was going to use. I saw many others complain about this also and I didn't think it would bother me but after a while it gets annoying.In the show Ray tried to say everything bad that happened was because of his father but in reality everything bad that happened was due to Abby. If she would have listened to her husband knowing how his father is then he wouldn't have shown up and none of this would have happened.I don't know if it is a given that the women characters are so annoying or what but they are just like they were in the Sopranos. Abby knew what she was getting into and was fine with all the money but then decided one day that wasn't good enough for her? The only decent female character was Lena. The rest were basically greedy and liked the money but wanted to complain about how it was made when it suited them.Update: Abby was annoying while she was alive but who knew that she would be even more annoying after she was dead. I sure hope they move on from her. They need to have Ray move on and stop with the flashbacks with her. A couple of shows for him to be sad and it should have moved on from there.

Looks like showtime did it again not gonna finish up the last season of 8 to have a closing. So tired of networks doing this like the faithful fans don't matter. Everyone needs to speak up. Our time matters too. Maybe time to drop showtime for a while till they figure out, the fans don't like this. Can't believe no ending all I can say is wow and showtime sucks!

I just finished on Prime season 5 - which I found to be the weakest collection of episodes dealing with the various levels of degeneracy of the Donovan clan. And for anyone wondering about the ambiguity left by the ending of the season 5 finale all questions should be answered by the announcement that there will be a season 6 with Ray moving to NYC. As I mentioned, so much of the plot lines and developments are quite preposterous as Ray, his brothers and the various cops, criminals and players get inflicted with more physical punishment than your average gladiator did in ancient Rome. Still, it's a fun series to watch in you have no objections to gratuitous violence, sex and profanity.Superb acting in this. Live Schreiber is compelling in the title role as is cable series queen Paula Malcomson as his long suffering wife Abby. But the best performer is screen veteran Jon Voight as Mickey Donovan, the ex-convict father of the three Donovan men. Voight steals every scene he is in as he is able to do one of the hardest tasks in acting-making a completely repulsive and utterly selfish character somewhat likeable. Unlike "The Sopranos" who managed to have lots of laughs (perhaps unintentionally) they are infrequent in most RD episodes, but they usually come from Voight. RD also brings back a number of actors older viewers will remember. Besides Voight, we have Elliot Gould as a sleazy attorney who hires Ray to cover up the various messes his celebrity clients get in, Susan Sarandon as an evil studio executive, Hank Azaria (Simpsons, Brockmire) as a crooked and kinky FBI bureau chief, James Woods as a veteran hitman, and even Paul Michael Glaser (tv's Starsky), Stacy Keach , Cheryl Ladd, Dabney Coleman, Diane Ladd and Ann Margaret in small roles.
