The first two seasons of Ray Donovan were exquisite, with a fabulous cast, strong writing, and a compelling plot that made this a true binge-watch. The third season was very nearly as good, but perhaps not quite so polished. Season Four, however, introduced a major story element that made my heart sink. Cancer. (Yep. That tired old soap-opera trope!)Now I should point out that my disappointment at the direction the show took was, of course, highly subjective. But I feel that if I had been adequately warned in advance about where things were heading plot-wise, I would NOT have spent the money to buy this otherwise excellent show. Because for very personal reasons I have a deep and powerful aversion to the subject of cancer, and watch shows like Ray Donovan SPECIFICALLY to escape from having to think about it. So my heart sank when it was introduced, and it sank even further when it became clear that the producers intended to use it as the MAJOR storyline going forward.However, I had paid the money, and the rest of the show continued to be high-quality and riveting. In fact, so compelling - during the brief interludes that didn't involve watching someone slowly dying from cancer - that I couldn't stop watching, even though the show was now a serious downer. I binge-watched the remaining two seasons (4 and 5) in one go. But it was more of an endurance event than the sheer delight that it had started out as.Season Five was a HUGE departure too, for stylistic as well as narrative reasons, and judged on its own merits would only have scored 2 stars from me. Aside from being a major downer due to the bulk of each episode being about multiple characters dying slowly from cancer, it also changed its storytelling style from a linear, straightforward narrative to a needlessly convoluted and messy miasma of flashbacks and flashforwards, crashing clumsily and confusingly backwards and forwards in time with no particular structure and nothing to ground the viewer or help them orient themselves in the story. Frankly it was a bleak, depressing, confusing mess. It also introduced another stylistic element that had previously been blissfully absent: Dream sequences and hallucinations. I passionately despise these things, as they are a lazy storytelling device, as well as being clichéd and annoying!However, and here's the thing with Ray Donovan; the bits of the show that actually focused on dodgy deals, hiding bodies, blackmailing scumbags, and managing the various disasters created by Mickey and his sons, remained as compelling as ever, and I still couldn't stop watching - despite not enjoying the majority of each episode.The show lost its way badly after its third season. But it is still a great series, with a top cast, excellent writing, and a gripping story. And based on what happened in the Season Five finale, I'm going to lay out more of my precious money to buy the next season ASAP - despite mostly hating the last 24 episodes I've watched. That's how good it is.

Ray Donovan (Season one).We follow Ray Donovan, who has a questionable work helping out rich people who gets in all sorts of problems. The end justifies the means and Ray, with a mix of distortion, threats, violence and murder, always gets the job done.Ray has a marriage that suffers both under his absence and lack of ability to show any kind of emotional response. He seems tired and burnout all the time as if he has been carrying a responsibility that is too big for to long. He is so expressionless that it at last gets on your nerves.Furthermore he has his two brothers. One with an alcoholic problem, that appears infantile, and another who has a boxing gym and a right arm with some odd motor deficit that you sense there is some secret behind.His father is released from prison after twenty years and season one can now begin.At one level Ray Donovan is action packed but at another a lot more is going on as the interaction between the characters is given much attention.The father, played brilliantly by Jon Voigt, enters the scene and shows us in a most convincing way what a life in prison does to your social abilities. He is full of good intentions but flunks again and again with his own belief that he can charm anybody with his superficial humor. He furthermore has an inappropriate language and to a certain degree moral values that has been in a time capsule for twenty years.The dynamics between Ray, his father and brothers are very engaging to watch but as far as the marriage goes the repeat button has been pushed too hard. The recipe is that his priority, without exception, is his job and his wife again and again, and yes again, shuts and yells at him for not being there while he leaves the scene often with a cell phone in his hand.There is much anger and bitterness on Rays part pointed at his father and the secret behind this slowly reveals itself with all the suspense this involves. This part is in my view the most exciting to watch and is beautifully intertwined with all the other stories that come to life.Regards SimonPs. He tries to do it without un-necessary violence but if push comes to shove he will shove. There ain't much he can not handle one way or another apart from problems caused by his own family and folks. - He can not 'push or shove' the ones he cares about. They don't understand the nature of his business or their problems, so they defy him, and by default he only manages to alienate them instead. They all demand the 'Truth' but as usual 'can not handle the truth' , ------ The stories are very well written, acting is quite good (by most if not all) - Ray is well portrayed as a tough macho with problem after problem piling up for him to manage. His wife Abby is also well portrayed as a neurotic, ungrateful bitch who although loves Ray and the kids, but somehow is under the delusion that she deserves more respect! Mickey the A*hole father is played very well by veteran Jon Voight. - I absolutely love the series, it is not perfect - but hey what is? - going back to those aforementioned criticisms, somehow, some people expect more real characters, more real situations, more real etc. - All I have to say to them is "Watch documentaries instead!" - this is fantasy, a story, a drama! . . . by definition it must be bigger than life - you want more "real" there are always "days of our lives" type soaps.

reviews.review_title: One of Showtime's best shows, continues to entertain
reviews.content: I caught up on all four seasons of this show this year, part of my renewed dedication to being a television blogger. I've taken in Lieve Schrieber's masterful performance over four years and forty-eight hours of television and found it both exciting and meditative. Showtime offers up some prestige television and Ray Donovan is at the top of this network. The show follows Ray as he fixes problems for Los Angeles rich and famous. The show picks up after an action-packed season finale of the third season with a shootout where Ray and his father Mickey Donovan (Jon Voight) took down the Armenian mob with the help of Ray's right-hand man Avi (Steven Bauer). Abby Donovan (Paula Malcomson) discovers that she has breast cancer and debates whether to seek treatment as she is upset with her husband and his promiscuous ways. Ray has to seek treatment himself for his alcohol addiction where he is introduced to the boxer Hector Campos (Ismael Cruz Cordova). Hector is seeking a title so begins to train at Ray's gym under the training of Ray's brother Terry (Eddie Marsan) who has Parkinson disease. Hector also has an incestuous relationship with his sister Marisol (Lisa Bonet). Ray's other brother Bunchy (Dash Mihok) has married the wrestler Teresa (Alyssa Diaz) but after her pregnancy, she suffers from postpartum depression. There are so many other great characters but another exceptional one is Lena (Katherine Moennig) who had a falling out with Ray but is back in the fold this season. Also, Ray's half-brother Daryll (Pooch Hall) is really funny as the comedic relief and I'm glad I've been seeing him in commercials recently. After Season Five: Ray Donovan (Liev Schreiber) returns for a mournful fifth season as the death of his wife Abby (Paula Malcomson) has caused him an immense amount of grief. It is not immediately revealed how Abby died the season is split between present-day drama and flashbacks of Abby's last days. Ray is in a drunken daze for most of the season as he copes with his grief. He is forced to attend anger management class after an incident involved his brothers and father and his daughter calling the cops. As the story plays through multiple times, Ray has problems in the present even if he isn't totally there to deal with them. HIs family is still up to no good and finding themselves in over their head with a ton of intense trouble. Abby was a sobering force for the Donovan family so leaving them behind with a bar leads naturally to chaos.Ray's daughter Bridget Donovan (Kerris Dorsey) seeks out a young man Smitty (Graham Rogers) who was denied treatment because Ray arranged it that Abby would receive the treatment. Something went wrong with Abby receiving the treatment but Smitty was pushed out so he is steadily dying. Terry Donovan (Eddie Marsan) has had his Parkinson assisted by a device that stops his shaking as he struggles with his own guilt over Abby's death. Bunchy Donovan (Dash Mihok) tries to make an investment with his settlement cash but ends up being robbed at a subway shop. Mickey Donovan (Jon Voight) is being harassed by FBI agent Frank Barnes (Michael McGrady) to kill Avi (Steven Bauer) who is smuggling drugs. He also helps Daryll (Pooch Hall) when one of his clients Jay White (Brian White) accidentally kills his sensai.Check out more of this review and others at swilliky.com

reviews.review_title: OK if you like caricatures and clichés
reviews.content: This has all the hallmarks of a great drama. Great actors, good base plot and good production. What lets it down is the script. It has more holes than Swiss cheese, some characters are unbelievable and the writing paints a picture of a main character (Ray) surrounded by morons. A family of inbred caricatures with the wife that undermines, kids that rebel, damaged brothers and neglectful father. Ray seems to spend most of his time herding his family like cats from one catastrophe to another. His job seems to be an extension of this with him problem solving for celebrities who mostly should be strapped to a chair and wearing nappies for their own safety. Associates and enemies of low IQ plotting or collaborating yet exhibit behaviour more reminiscent of kindergarten than the street. Essentially the series is let down by attempts at bringing some dark humour to characters and situations that turns out to be clumsy and in some instances ridiculous. E.g. a loner FBI agent in his secret basement tells a convicted murderer informant that his investigation is totally secret and gets shot in the head for his troubles... really!? The result is a potentially slick drama let down by lack of creativity and innovation in the writing.

reviews.content:

Ray Donovan...the only reason I knew the new season had started was because I logged into IMDB and the background was adverting Ray Donovan. I am not sure why there are so many negative reviews for this season. This is by far the best season to date. Well written and superbly acted. This show finally got away from some of the silly storylines with a very thoughtful script. Easily one of the best shows on TV this year.

reviews.review_title: The Sopranos meets Calabasas (well, sort of)
reviews.content: First, let me clear the air: The Sopranos is and will be not only the greatest crime drama, but one of the best shows on television, period. That's why it is so hard to avoid comparing Ray Donovan with the Sopranos.Still, there are some similarities - A troubled relationship with one's parents, a dysfunctional family, jealous wife, FBI on your back... The list is endless. But I'd say that it's unfair to dismiss Ray Donovan as another Sopranos clone because most mob movies/TV shows follow the same premise. Instead, I'll focus on the good stuff, and there is plenty of it.First of all, Liev Schreiber is amazing, a rare talent and I dare to say one of the best looking men in Hollywood. Seriously, someone should send George Clooney a farewell. Having spent some time in Massachusetts, I can say that his Boston accent is spot on! There is of course Jon Voight, the legend he is, playing Ray's father Mickey.The story is not the most original, but don't forget people like Ray ("fixers") have existed in the world of rich and famous for eternity, and the show offers us a rare insight in their world. I also love the subplot involving sex abuse scandals in Catholic church, a problem that only a few shows have touched so far.Why 9 out of 10 then? Well, the chemistry between Ray and Mickey is simply amazing, but it could get more screen time.With Masters Of Sex and Ray Donovan, Showtime has another winner.

reviews.review_title: 6 for the acting and camera work
reviews.content: If one watches a lot of these shows now one has to come to the conclusion that psychos, sociopaths and amoral people are the heroes of our time. Ray is maybe two of these or all of these. The new type of writing always shows the personal side of these people--oh, he has a family and he is a loving husband /father. This was true as well in the vastly popular 'Sopranos'. They're not truly bad, just motivated by love of family. They don't really break the law--they just follow the trends like the Stock Market, twisting it a bit. His brother hates and would kill all homosexuals but he's really just a good kid who was molested (BTW, I was 15 too once and I never met a healthy male teen who could be made to do anything they didn't want to--just ask their parents and peers.). His wife isn't a former hooker or dominatrix, she's just a girl who didn't have the opportunity to get much education. His daughter isn't a borderline on the rise--she's just being a teen. His father isn't a bad ex-con, he just got some bum deals in life and wanted to avenge his son's bad priest homo abusers. Let's all rally round the 'deez, dem, doze' boys and show them how much we appreciate all they've done to bring culture into our world. The one saving grace of the this show is that it probably comes closest to revealing the real Hollywood as it is and was. People with money and power are always corrupt. Macbeth will always do the wrong thing but that's why we like him and identify with him isn't it? I used to watch film and tv to escape the horrors of life; now it just pulls me down even further into it. I used to read about man's atrocities to man. Now CGI brings it home so I can actually see people beheaded, brains splatter, rape, torture--all in 3D!!! Lucky us!!!!

Everything is brilliant about this show. This is why I like watching TV shows. Well done Showtime. One of the greatest, well written, well acted, directed & produced show. Gutted they canceled the show just like that without a proper ending. Just goes to show that Showtime doesn't really care about the art of making a good show.

Ugly faces and it all began to look like Soprano re-runs without the sheer coldness of Tony.
VERY disappointing for me

reviews.review_title: I Won't Miss a Single Episode !
reviews.content: This series gets a 10 from me because it's the only series that I absolutely will not miss an episode of. Anti hero Ray goes through life like so many of us, thinking he does what he does for his family. But his dedication to his work -as well as his code of ethics-only causes everyone who loves him to eventually leave him alone. Character driven drama with enough humour and violence to whet my whistle every week.

This season has changed for the worst. Maybe the series has run it's course. Major changes in chacters e.g. Mickey was a likable shady individual- now he is a unlikeable dumb hood. Ray has turned into a murder.

Is it just me......how can so many cast and crew (41 producers!!) miss so many actual glaring errors. I started out loving this show in Season 1 & 2, but then it seemed to go downhill from there. Also, since I am not a fan of flipping back and forth in time, it became somewhat confusing on many occasions. It did not help that the main characters mumbled half their lines. Have never had to turn the volume up so high, or rerun scenes to get the dialogue and...I still missed some. Mind you, 90% of their dialogue was 'f...', very easy to learn their lines I guess 👎🏻Jon Voight's character had, without a doubt, the absolute best writing for his character AND played his role to 't'. Not sure if he ever was nominated for his role, but he sure as hell should have been.Season 6 was an utter waste of time. Became like an action movie for kids. Really....Ray leaps out of a window which appeared to be 2 or 3 storeys high, then gets up and climbs a huge wall...come on. Totally ridiculous.I will not be watching Season 7...I give up!

It's a mix of Sam Spade + L. A. Confidential + The Boxer + an Irish Sopranos...It's also a bit top heavy in the plot department, with at least 7 or 8 threads in the first episode alone. It's so busy I began to wonder if it was a parody. I may watch the next episode but it had better grab me or that's it. It stars Liev Schreiber, Jon Voight, Elliott Gould. It features gay actors, lesbian secretaries, child molesting priests, drunken boxers, mixed race children, voyeurs, stalkers, sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll and many more devices too cliché too mention. Very standard stuff for today. You can practically write the script in your head as you watch.

I saw that many reviews here state this would be boring and slow, or that the characters are cliché and unreal.Well, first off, this show does not spell out every single action for you, it expects you to be emotionally intelligent enough to understand many things in the plot without feeding it to you word by word. It is a fantastic show, especially for those non-spoken, highly emotional things, but you simply have to have the brains to get that.Secondly, the characters are not unreal, oh no. Maybe not everyone can live in a villa in Hollywood, true, but as for the rest? Like it or not but 90% of families are that f+++d up actually in one way or another, only picket fences on the outside and I love the fact how they transport this in that show totally in your face. I actually think people get quite uncomfortable witnessing this, and in one form or another, even if in a way more harmless form, they know it from their own family life experiences how messed up families can be. I personally think it's brilliant how this show transports the conflicts and relationships between the family members, how important father-children relationships are, not only when you are a child but also, or even more, when you are an adult. Observed in a perfect way from a psychological point of view. Third, it also shows very realistically (and again very uncomfortably) how dramatic the lifelong consequences can be for victims of sexual child abuse. And how different (depending on the resilience one individually has or doesn't have) victims are able to cope with it and in what ways.And last, I have to grin a bit, about some comments here from guys stating how a guy almost 50 can wear tight pants like Ray Donovan. Jealous much? - you'd have all reason to be, so you are forgiven ;)

reviews.review_title: Best new Dramatic TV in a long time.
reviews.content: I don't know what other shows these reviews are coming from, (the ones that are negative about this show), but I really like this show. It's like the modern day version of the Soprano's with an Irish twist and the Jewish faith added for spice. The action seasons are so real like and to see Jon Voight in this series really adds credibility to the show. The only flaw I see is Ray's wife, I am not sure if I like her character and I would of rather they selected someone else for the role. Not that I don't like red heads, I just don't think she is as hot as she should be. I would of figured Ray to be with a woman that's a 9-10 compared to one that is still hot at a 7-8. Other than that I am hooked and can't wait to watch the next episode. I am sure the Catholic religion would wish it goes away real soon. I hope it stays around for many seasons to come.

Like so many shows to come out of America in recent times, Ray Donovan follows the story of a successful character, who lives the high life, with important friends and women all around him.Like all these characters, he has inner demons that he has to face, and a family that he loves, but whom he is slowly losing in the struggle to balance his work and personal life. The context of the show is like we've seen so many times in recent television, however this is much better.After the first couple episodes, I guarantee you will be hooked. This show is clever and full of action. Liev Schreiber is an excellent actor and portrays the role convincingly. He does not over-act, in the contrary, he is quiet and introverted, which emphasises the mysterious nature of this complex and charismatic character.This is the best action/mystery show to come out of America in a long time. The only complaint I have is the actor who plays Ezra (Elliot Gould) is quite painful to watch, then again, he does play the role of a crazy man. Get into this guys it's worth watching.

reviews.review_title: I liked the 1st 2 seasons- hated Seasons 5 &6
reviews.content:
I want to write this without spoilers- OK, I was willing to watch a flawed show, that was interesting. Yes, he is violent, often unlikable. He starts out as an anti-hero- yes he's ad but something to like, with a kind of personal integrity which erodes, except that he wants to protect family (not the father) By S#3- it got silly. too much with unfaithful Ray & his career criminal, just came out of jail, misogynist Father. The father really is  toxic. No, I don't like John Voight, maybe since Midnight Cowboy. Elliot Gould plays a rather despicable Studio owner, again a character not to love. But I was hooked & continued to watch.
S#5 really hated it; to show a non linear narrative. (meaning tell a story by going back & forth in time) beside flashbacks, new material, was now, than back than forward again. I got whiplash. Hated the main plot points. the end of S#5 was really unrealistic, even for cliché TV.
Again I want to avoid spoilers-
S#6 they do a complete reboot- Calif Ray is now starting life again in NewYork. this is the sort of thing that can be done successfully, Weeds, Orange is the New Black. not here. He brings his family along.
S#5 in Hollywood & S#6 NYC Susan Sarandon is a main character. Hate her. I mean really hate her. read a quote on line, she wouldn't mind if they gave her and Ray a romantic story line. In your dreams Susan.
There is some interesting, some cliché, some highly questionable story lines & plot points.
but S#5 & S#6 made me wonder what I had ever seen in the show.
new S#7, starts soon. Will I watch, prob. eventually, when I see Showtime again. But I have stopped watching shows mid episode.
It's a train wreck you can't stop watching like someone said.

Overall premise of Season 2 seems to be flawed.Everyone is acting like the killing of Sully on the docks was illegal and must be covered up. No one wants to tell the reporter Kate McPherson what really happened. But what happened wasn't actually illegal. On the shore line Sully shot Ray's private eye in the stomach. Sully was in the process of stealing Ray's money (hit money he was going to pay Sully with) even though he hadn't earned it (hadn't killed Ray's father Mickey). At gunpoint he was jumping a boat to leave the country. It's possible he was going to kill Ray, Mickey, and maybe even his partner Tiny before that boat shoved off. So Mickey shooting him was self-defense. Self-preservation. So why are they all so afraid to let the truth come out? Didn't the FBI agent who was there (and who got shot by Ray) tell the FBI that it was self defense? I don't get it. Sully was a murderer.I have to say this is the only problem I have with the show. I love it otherwise. I have been renting all the episodes. I like watching how Ray handles crises with efficiency and a certain kind of fairness and justice. The bad guys get what's coming to them.

Bring back Ann Biderman NOW! The first three seasons were must see TV. Season Four seems to be a film school senior project and that's probably insulting to them. I have to wonder what happened in Season Four? The writing stinks and the story is so weak. All the characters except for Ray have been reduced to props. Terry, Avi, Lena, and Daryll have nothing to do. Mickey has become a dottering old fool, not the street-smart con we've come to know and love. Ray seems to have lost his balls. Singing Karaoke to get information instead of beating it out of the guy? This season Ray's constantly running from one place to another like a soccer mom with four kids on four different teams. How many trips has he made to Nevada this season? This is not the Ray Donovan from the first Three Seasons. Montages are used to fill time because the writers have hit a dead end with the plot. They're also pulling characters out of their butts to come up with something to try and make this season make some sense. All of a sudden we learn Ezra had another fixer? Abby gets diagnosed with Stage 0 breast cancer and ends up making out with her oncologist, Lena's conveniently cast former girl friend, in a strip bar? Conor overnight becomes an incorrigible gangster wanna be? It goes on and on. Character development and background has become non-existent whereas we really got to know everyone during the first three seasons.After Episode 2 this season I had hope things were getting better. Alas, it was not to be. The episodes keep getting worse. But I'll keep watching this train-wreck and hope that it gets better. If not, well, there's always next season.

reviews.review_title: What of the greatest I've ever seen
reviews.content: I only started this show because it seemed interesting and the cast was good. This show is now one of my favorite shows ever, the cast is amazing and should be racking up awards left and right. This show should have more awards, especially for Liev Schreiber. This show is a must watch for anyone who likes a good drama.

Having watched and enjoyed Seasons 1-3 on Netflix some time ago, we began wondering when it might return. So, we picked up the DVD of Season 5, soon to realize from the gaping holes in the plot that we should have gone for Season 4. All I can say is Season 5 is a hodge-podge of flashbacks to the degree there's very little of what made Ray Donovan so good in earlier seasons. Scenes flip back and forth in time, often with little clue that's what's happening. Half the time, you can't even tell what city the story has moved to, or why. Buried under layers of family squabbles, there's a plot afoot concerning a movie studio or production house, but it seems like an afterthought. Any hope of "picking up" the story even though you missed earlier episode is pointless. Inserting temporal flashbacks into a story takes a certain level of skill so they actually move the narrative along without being confusing. Ray Donovan Season 5 fails to deliver.

I've watched close to the entire series and even though it go's far out it's done well. The entire family becomes rounded and you end up caring for the characters. It's a very intense series and thrives in constant trauma but not like a soap opera (which I can't stand). It's not an upbeat show that's for sure but it's done so well that I stuck with it. Solid

I love the storyline and the acting. I really hope that more shows like this one will be made in future. The show has a quiet intensity that is brilliant and stimulates emotions in me like most shows don't.I'm an all or nothing kind of guy so I rate this 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Shame on YOU Showtime!... for canceling one the best show ever!
reviews.content:
I'm watching season 5 and just find out they cancel the show for no reason!.. I am Shocked!... why do you cancel one of the best show in history?! I search and nothing found. even the Creators don't understand this Bad Horrible decision!
Don't do this to DonFans! they deserve more and complete story!...
I hope they reconsider it and bring back the show. but if they're not,... Shame on you Showtime! SHAME ON YOU!

Love this series even more because I'm Irish. Ray Donovan is a family man, he runs his business taking care of celebrities and any other problem that comes his way. If you're famous and you wake u beside a dead body then Ray Donovan the man gonna take care of it. He probably works for the Clinton family. Only thing I hate is his wife, omg all she does is nag and complain about everything. She's even worse than Walt's wife in Breaking Bad. Women like her are the reason I never got married.

I watched this after a friend recommended it. Our opinions diverge. The central conflict, between Ray and his father, is introduced immediately, and it's not the most interesting one. It doesn't help that I have never liked Jon Voight as an actor. According to my friend the show will continue to circle around this basic conflict for the rest of the show, which made me give up in the middle of the second season. If I'm not interested by then, after having invested almost 20 hours, then it's never going to happen. For being a "fixer" Ray does a surprisingly little amount of actual fixing. In the end this show is more like a family style soap, albeit dour.

reviews.review_title: When you have a great character development, you don't need a lot of gunshots and special effects to make a good TV show.
reviews.content: 2017 and I'm starting to see these TV show. Well, I'm a TV show junkie and I consider myself a man who saw all the great TV shows post 2000: Game Of Thrones, Breaking Bad, Lost, Fargo, True Detective, The Walking Dead and now Westworld and the list goes on and goes on, so, came a moment when you're starting to lose the patient because when you see all the 5 stars show, you have to get used with the other ones and the rating and quality of the show will come down, no doubt, it comes with the territory. So, I give it a chance to Ray Donovan and I'm not disappointed. Jon Voight and Liv Schreiber duo are probably one of the best in the history of television along with Paul and Carson in BB or McConaughey and Harrelson in True Detective. If you're an adrenaline junkie that likes the TV shows with the emotion of interminable fights and a lot of gun and gunshots, these show is not for you. But, if you like an amazing character development, with a good, controversial and emotional plot, I totally recommend these one.

reviews.review_title: Binge Worthy Series w Bad Daughter
reviews.content:
This series is One Of The Best Ever!Most of the storylines are plausible. The challenging situations Ray's clients are faced with and the multitude of manipulation tactics employed against the Shows Marks ring True for "Magical Spell-Casting Land." All Credit can be given to the writers for dialogue and scene structure, but I have No Doubts that many of these stories stem from actual experiences and stories they've heard while schmoozing around L. A. :)First...
An observation I've made about some of the older and more recent series I've been binge watching lately. Many of the Lead Characters Daughter's have similar traits.Abby n Ray's daughter, Bridget is a Disrespectful, Entitled, Wannabe Grown Ass, Annoying, and Unattractive to put it kindly tbh. She's constantly mouthing off to her parents from the very beginning of the series. The fact that both parents allow it believing that it's the cool thing to do, refusing to keep a child in a child's place by creating and enforcing any boundaries of respect or discipline is a symptom of the illness that plagues so many families today.I would never in a million years, even "think" about disrespecting my parents by saying or acting the way she, and many other TV series daughters do! Nor would my Wife and I allow "Our Grown Adult Children" to disrespect in any way. Fortunately we've raised them with enough respect to know better.Second...
The storyline that a Hot Young Rapper that can have any Fine Ass Female out there but chooses to pursue Bridget's Ugly Ass because she's "Real," is Totally Ridiculous, as well as Insulting to our intelligence and sense of taste!!!As I've started to notice in many of the recent series that have young daughters depicted.. They're all following the same script type for the Daughters; Mouthy, pretentious, disrespectful, little "biatches.." Really!?Is this what society wants to impress on their kids these days? Please don't allow your kids to follow this template.There's a time and a place for kids to act grown, and that's when they leave your house! Not when they're preteens or teens, living under your roof! And... Never.. Yes, Never.. should they feel free to speak to You, their Parents, any old way they feel like it and/or Pass Judgement on your Life. As long as you are a Good Parents and are providing for them the best way you can. Anyway... I just had to get that outta my system and into the world. :)That being said, Ray Donovan is Still one of My Top 10 Series of All Time.In fact, I'm Binge watching it again at the time of this writing. It is an Extremely Entertaining, Well Acted, Well Written, and Directed Series.Perfect for You To Binge Watch Right Now Too!

reviews.review_title: This Show Just Didn't Do It For Me
reviews.content: This isn't a completely negative review. I understand Ray Donovan is extremely popular, finishing up its 7th season. My wife and I tried to watch it. We made it through the first six episodes of Season One. We looked at each other and said, "No.". Why? Not really sure. We think that it may be we are tired of dysfunctional family-series. And Ray Donovan is certainly that! No problem with the acting. Writing is mostly okay. But we have watched soooo many similar shows. We enjoyed all 7 seasons of Sons of Anarchy. Really good. Sopranos? Of course. Yellowstone is quite good, too. And today you can't do feel-good 1950's Ozzie-and-Harriet type shows. They just wouldn't sell. But after a while the dysfunctional family stuff gets wearing and boring. If it doesn't, you might enjoy Ray Donovan. For us, enough!

reviews.review_title: Ray Donovan series don't leave please
reviews.content: Wow o enjoyed movie last night. Yes think Ray still alive and could say self defense in shooting of his Dad Mick. Will miss him too. reviews.review_title: Over-the-top melancholic crime drama without fear of holding back.
reviews.content: Season 1: 7.5/10 The first season of Ray Donovan is supposed to be a crime drama, but couldn't help becoming a melancholic Shakespearean tragedy. Casting-wise, this show excels, despite being too overcrowded with characters and subplots of subplots. Each scene is pretty explosive and entertaining on its own, but is everyone necessary and vital for the progress of the plot? Most of the time the answer is a massive "No". But do I regret watching Jon Voight enjoying the living crap out of himself in a gay club? Most of the time the answer is a massive "Yes". So in general the season is both guilty and not guilty for its shenanigans,just like its characters.The motif of sinning and forgiving is fundamental to the series, with the little brother Bunchy Donovan (masterfully played by Dash Mihok) lying at the core of the conflict. As I already said, individually every character shines in their individual scenes, but few of them contribute to the story. Well, except a "son" character with questionable sexual orientation, he might as well not exist. The Donovans is spectacular, Ray's co-workers are campy badasses and Jon Voight basically chews your TV screen. The family is alright enough, it does the job to judge the main character for his every step. The second act really picks up when a guest, legendary old school actor joins the cast, unfortunately the ending fizzles out too quickly . What I hope happens with this show is that it stops taking itself so overly serious and starts contributing more screen time for its hilarious black humor. Some episodes you feel the struggle in the journey of self-discovery and I have faith that in Season 2, the series will find its groove.Conclusion: The first season of Ray Donovan is a fun, over-the-top melanchonic journey of self-discovery for both the show and its characters, with tones shifting left and right. Worth watching for the outstanding performances and a terrific cast. And possibly Jon Voight alone.7.9/10 During Ray Donovan's sophomore season, the show gets to play Capitan. After a couple episodes I felt like I finally was understanding the tone and the abundant amount of charm that the series was going for. It is still far away from being perfect, but I have begun to love it for the gritty and stylish atmosphere, well supported by its magnificent cast. I rarely feel this way about similar shows, but every character is truly fascinating. Even the obnoxious kids and the moody wife are more than my descriptions of them suggest. The man himself, Liev Schreiber absolutely kills it as Ray Donovan. You can feel the miniature domino that gets pushed at him every single episode, triggering a chain of events leading to his soul-wrecking change in the finale. Every single one of his brothers has an arc, that doesn't waste the acting abilities of the actors. The supporting cast is quirky and rich in character. And the never-ending highlight of the show is still Jon Voight's Mickey Donovan. During his scenes you start to perceive the tragic events in a more lighthearted matter. He is still an abnormally big jerk, but he brings much needed levity to everything happening and you clearly see that he'll get completely mad if he takes all the trainwrecks happening around him seriously. I particularly liked the great use of a returning character that didn't bring much to the table the first time around. The major negative aspect of the show is how conveniently the story plays out. Some things just happen for the sake of happening, so the plot could progress. You could say that's part of the show's charm, but it might bother some people. The most unexpected thing this season was the possession of Abby. It was like the demon inside Skyler from Breaking Bad was bored from its vessel and decided to enter someone else. Why the producers decided to make Abby completely insufferable is beyond my knowledge.Conclusion: You may have noticed how I used the word "play" in the beginning, as the show still has a road to go to deserve its place behind the steering wheel. Yet there is so much charm to help you overlook the flaws. I place my confidence in the third season to be even better and to elevate the show to a "Capitan".

It was 3:30 am, my eyes hurt, but I couldn't put myself to sleep. How was Ray going to save himself and his family this time? I mean surely, this time he was way over his head. The Russian Mafia wasn't going to let things slide and Barnes wasn't the pussy he once was. In the middle of Rattus Rattus, my stomach made odd grumbling noises. I was out of snacks. Surely, the nailbiting finish wouldn't occur without some chips and chai. Having waited till 5:30 am, I cycled to the nearest store. Boy, it was worth every single crumb.Ray Donovan is terrific. The characters are real. They are brutal and oh so human. Ray is no angel and neither is his family. A bunch of crooks, getting saved at the nick of time by some excellent editing. Spotlight brought Liev out in the open to larger audiences. The summary on Netflix wasn't so compelling, but Liev made me want to give it a shot. Four seasons later, I can't wait for more.Jon Voight is a gem. What a stellar performance. Having done 20 years for a crime he did not commit, he surely isn't going to live a saintly life now. His role as Mickey is nothing short of iconic. The black humour he generates with his subtle expressions and dialogue delivery is worthy of the highest appreciation. Mickey's character is loathsome, but it's surely Voight's expertise that I hoped throughout that nothing bad should happen to him.Bunchy and Terry are complex characters played with some supreme finesse.What a friggin' show. Fan for life.

reviews.review_title: This used to be my favorite show....
reviews.content: I loved this show. With the exception of Ray's utterly useless teenage kids characters this show was near perfect. But this new season? Absolutely horrid so far. Bordering on the unwatchable. It seems like a few episodes were skipped and so now we have the dubious pleasure of revisiting those skipped episodes via endless flashbacks. Now speaking for myself I think unless you are making "Memento" shows should legally be barred from using more than 2 flashbacks per episode period. This season thus far is about 15% "new" stuff and 85% annoying flashbacks. Some of which repeat. NOTHING actually seems to be happening this season. Instead of maybe devoting two or three proper episodes to what the writers are trying to tell us via the endless flashbacks it seems like the writers are treading water until they can think of an actual compelling plot line for this new season. My girlfriend is very close to the point of giving up on the series entirely and I am not far behind. This show has gone from quite possibly the best show out there to barely watchable. If the writers and producers did not have any material for this season then maybe they should have just skipped this season altogether. Or like I said earlier: just wrapped up the Abby and kids BS with a few episodes and then skip the rest until inspiration struck again. My vote, by the way, is for how season 5 is developing thus far. Otherwise I'd have given this a 10 based on the previous seasons.

If you like to watch the Freeway, PCH, rich and powerful, petty, anxious people, like mindless sex and violence you'll like this show. reviews.review_title: The best show in a long time..
reviews.content: I just finished viewing the 1st season and it was great. Ray's character is near perfect - he is a tormented bully with a heart of gold. He is a real "old time" stereotype which is GREAT - finally a hero which resembles people we knew and are now old. a REAL man. He is no saint but he does what he does out of total loyalty and complete family devotion (and screwing a bit around doesn't count - just like real man of old) he is the guy we are all missing today with all the metro-sexual crap. People are complaining about Abby's character - but she is perfect - she was a rough neighborhood unspoiled girl who married a man she crazy about but struggles with his shortcomings. She is clearly not the mommy type but she is doing everything to overcome who she was and be a loving mother. Not perfect and that's what makes it so good. She is trying to care and spoil the children but also wants her own peace and quiet. The plot is clear and the characters are down to earth with a twist. Nothing makes me happier in an era where flimsy screen writers are giving us promises and not delivering. The cast is great from the tortured soul of Ray which seems to have been tailored for Liev Schreiber which is doing a wonderful job. He wears Ray Donovan like a glove. He brothers are the good Irish boys who enjoy fighting and drinking and love their big brother. Eddie Marsan is doing a wonderful work as the conscience of the family whose loyalty keeps him quiet. And both bothers take care of the "little boy" - a challenging character which has still more to develop done by Dash Mihok in a good way. I believe with the right script for him he will be much better. And finally the wonderful Jon Voight whose acting is free and adds a contrast to Ray's dark and serious nature (well after all Micky is the reason Ray is like that..). And the brushing of the screen with great actors like Elliott Gould, James Woods and Rosanna Arquette (a nice comeback!) only makes it better. And finally, Ray's sidekicks are a nice mix of the funny ex-Mossad Avi (Steven Bauer in a great comeback as well! - i hope they don't kill him because Ray's character really needs Avi to pull all he does) and Lesbian Lena which deserves a story of her own... And for all Trekkies.. Denise Crosby closes the comeback line :-)Thanks for a GREAT Show!! Give us more of the SAME!! Don't change Ray - don't make him mushy-soft now that we know what happened to him - we don't need him sitting on a couch. He is a man - and men deal with it!!

Any moron could do the same thing- Just give them what they ask for.I feel let down because Liev Schreiber on screen stature is diminished by his pussyfooting methods.Of course I am not looking for a constant blood bath when issues need to be resolved, but I just feel the sometimes feeble approaches used make Ray Donovan look incompetent.

reviews.review_title: The O'Sopranos. Derivative, shallow, but catchy, like an annoying pop tune.
reviews.content: Ray Donovan is a 'noir-soap' about a violent Hollywood fixer whose constant, melodramatic family issues outweigh the dirty jobs he has to do, like the 'Black Cube' organisation.Jon Voight has a whale of a time as Ray's father, a tricky trouble-maker, in a blatant tribute to The Soprano's unlovable 'Uncle Pauly'. Paula Malcolmson as Ray's wife Abby, is nothing more than a Boston Irish Carmela Soprano, while Liev Schreiber as Ray is a kind of ripped Tony Soprano with a Lord Alan (UK Apprentice) Sugar stubble-beard. Steven Bauer, Breaking Bad's Don Eladio, is great, among many brilliant supporting cast turns. Shame the lead characters are also two-dimensional - not the actors' fault btw.There's a lot of Sopranos-style black humour of characters turning perfectly ordinary social events into disasters. Women get short shrift; prostitutes or sex objects, black people seem all to be dangerous in some way, and Ray's clientele, the power brokers of Hollywood, are all out-neuroticizing Woody Allen.Many venerable actors, apart from Voight, are wheeled out to top up the ham quota. Not so much stunt casting as 'stent' casting. Elliot Gould, I'm afraid, is worse than he was as Ross's father in 'Friends'; he can't act and speak at the same time.It says it all, really, that the therapist (yes, there's a therapist) is played by Mr Data from Star Trek. Well played, but still. Spot the android.Ironically, considering that its model The Sopranos was left open-ended, Ray Donovan was unceremoniously cancelled without warning after seven seasons. Watchable, but annoyingly derivative in places.

It does have some well-known actors, which was a promising thing and I thought it could deserve the 8/10 rating it has. But the thing is, it really is full of clichés and over-the-top-nonsense-drama.One of the biggest problems is the messy story - it just goes in every direction and while it's not even too hard to follow, just doesn't make ANY sense. It's (randomly) entertaining, but sadly made of clichés following clichés. The next bad thing about the show is the fact that Paula Malcomson can't decide which accent to use. It really drives me crazy when she first speaks using the American-like accent and then she slips out to use her original accent - and sometimes they happen to mix between sentences! This happens way too often (in every episode) and makes her performance look amateurish. I think she was much better on Sons Of Anarchy. Not all characters are completely terrible, I like Terry and a few others like Avi. I hate the fact that this makes really good actors look really bad. reviews.review_title: lacks soul...it's struggling to be good
reviews.content: There's some great ideas here...i truly believe if this show had better writers...it would be a masterpiece...the first episode...which is supposed to be the intro to the show...it's terrible...it's rushed...too many things happening...almost degenerates into some shonda rhimes trash montage...it crams too many things into one episode jesus christ!!...take it slow!...but aside from the pilot that tries to build some intricacy a little too fast for its own good...the rest of the episodes fall into place neatly...as the episodes keep rolling in...it gets better...there's some decent episodes somewhere in there....the more than occasional sloppy acting is a very big flaw though...the grandpa and the agent are very horribly acted...Ray's demeanour is a little off...seems a little too robotic...some characters though should not have got as much screentime as they do...especially Ray's wife and the black kid...soo uncompelling...i don't care about them at all...soo unnecessary...just a bit of screentime for world-building...don't give them subplots...jesus!!...it makes no sense!!!...Ray's shaky hand brother isn't too bad though...in the beginning i was so proud of this show...coz it was roaming free and not submitting to any trope of any genre...it was just a show about nothing...and it managed to keep this up for a good number of episodes...but a couple of episodes in and it starts to fall apart...the atrocious subplots...and you start to realize that it only has one trick up its sleeve that it keeps recycling over and over...and suddenly it becomes just another badly written terribly acted glorified pile of nothing...it bends logic a little too much...some plot points are too ridiculous....a random example...they want to build up the wife into a serious character...but for the kind of character they're trying to sell...she takes soo much nonsense from Ray...who shows little to no emotion or affection...doesn't talk to her...disrespects her...is barely a husband or father...this does happen yes...but it's inconsistent with her character...if i had to sum it up in a few words...I'd say it's not a terrible show...but it lacks soul and is just left desperately trying to be good...

I'll give it four stars because I actually made it to the end of the first season, so I have to give it some props for that. I don't mind a bit of the old ultra-violence every now and then as long as it's in context, but I'm not into a steady diet of sadistic violence and this show has that aplenty. It just strains credulity to believe that the members of one family can perpetrate so much mayhem and never get caught or held accountable. It also strains credulity that these miscreants can smoke, drink, do drugs, all to major excess, yet still be able to perform feats of superhuman strength and endurance without any kind of indication of what they do to stay in shape. By the time the last episode of Season 1 rolled around, I knew I had made the right decision to ditch the show. The scene on the docks where Micky turns his gun on Sully was telegraphed from a mile away. Just another example of the kind of cheap, clichéd writing that otherwise marred a promising initial run of episodes. Too bad, considering the talent involved, especially Elliot Gould who should consider his involvement in this exercise in pandering to an audience's basest instincts as a major "shonda."

This series is good. I enjoyed watching it even more the second time. It is one of those good productions: the first time you take in the action, the second time you concentrate on how it is done. Let's be clear: everything about this series and every episode of it is predictable. There is nothing here which hasn't been done before, one way or another. But predictable doesn't have to mean bad. Shakespeare is predictable, cartoons are (were) predictable and video games are predictable. Done well, they can all be excellent. That's what makes this series good: good acting and genuine depth in how the stories are told.The series is constructed around two pillars with Ray Donovan (Live Schreiber) at their centre: who he is and what he does.First, what he does: Ray heads a small team of cleaners, in Los Angeles, a city with a lot of trash. He and his team are action arm of a small law firm (headed by the always excellent Elliott Gould) focused on a recession proof business model. They clean and fix the lives of the rich and famous. The rich and famous can be relied upon to destroy whatever they touch; they can also be relied upon to gratefully hand over a lot of cash, without questions or arguments, in exchange for Ray's services and his miraculous capacity to piece together their crashed lives. This in itself makes the series highly enjoyable. Seeing how silly, stupid, shallow, mean and disaster-prone the 0.1% is plays to our Schadenfreude and makes us satisfied with our more modest lives.Second, who he is: this is even more predictable. He is the alpha-male of four brothers, from a Boston-Irish family which has relocated to California to get away from the father. The series starts with the early release from prison of Mickey Donovan (Jon Voight), their father. Mickey is can't wait a minute to join his sons in California and take up where he left it: wreck their lives. He is charming, fun and indulgent, and at his most indulgent with himself. He worms his way into Ray's home, wife and his two teenagers. Of the four brothers Ray is the only one who has managed to create a normal family. We understand quickly where the feeling of doom in Ray, as he witnesses his father's return, comes from. He has been the father to his brothers, and a sister whom we only know as a distant and painful memory, while Mickey has always avoided any feeling of responsibility. There are all the usual ingredients: alcoholism, pedophile priest, vengeful and demanding wife, teenagers adoring the simple lessons of their grandfather: responsibility bad, indulgence good.What makes the series work well is how the two schematic parts connect, with Ray at their centre. Seeing everything he has built for his wife, children and brothers, predictably and inexorably destroyed by his no-good father, he somehow does his job and even manages to channel his private rage into his work.

reviews.review_title: Interesting and Exciting Show With Extra Drama Tagged On.

It has to do with the side stories and some of the characters within them. The older brother's love life, the kids and their growing pains, the spiteful wife and her distrust, they're taking me out of the flow of an otherwise exciting main story line. Especially the wife parts really bug me. And while I do realize this is a drama series and that these happenings influence the main protagonist in one way or another it comes across as fluff to me filling up the spacing in between, extra filling that is just not as interesting to me as the main story line and as I mentioned before, breaks the flow of a great show for me which in turn unfortunately affects my urge to continue watching it. reviews.review_title: Ray The fixer becomes the destroyer.

Now the series is hard to stay on course with and is often dark and depressing, and sure any story needs conflict but Ray is out of control. No longer the fixer that people relied upon, Ray is now the destroyer. As a result from killing off key characters the story is often bland and repetitive. It seems to have steered away from the original idea of a Hollywood fixer to a brutal thug drunk committing career suicide and this severe story arc is so far gone from the first 2 seasons and the Ray that we rooted for. I liked the characters of Lee Drexler and Ezra Goldman but they no longer exist along with many others. I don't know, I guess I miss the old Ray. I remain watching due to the immense acting and being a fan of the show I wait in hope for Ray to return to old ways which appears to be the common theme having read other reviews. As season 6 approaches, yet again as in seasons 4 & 5 the old Ray may just be further away than ever as he takes on New York.

Plot is really weak-If this guy is such an effective cleaner for Hollywood Elite, why wouldn't he just have someone knock off his father in prison? reviews.review_title: First two seasons are great, the next two are garbage. (from a viewer who binge watched)
reviews.content: Maybe I have a different opinion of the show since I watched all four seasons one after another. What I can definitely say is that there's an obvious arc whereby the show goes from exciting, dangerous, and dark, to just plain stupid and beyond realistic.My review will begin on seasons 1-2. Ray is clearly an unhappy person, rarely smiles or shows any type of emotion whatsoever. His kids are typical teenagers with typical problems, some of which are amplified due to Ray's profession. His wife, Abby, sticks out like a sore thumb with her Boston upbringing. She can be extremely irritating. Their relationship leaves much to be desire and you wonder why she stays. The dysfunction is overwhelming. What is worth watching is how Ray performs his job with precision, like a robot. The people who need him are narcissists, rich, and with serious problems only Ray can make go away. Many of them are extremely obnoxious, including his boss, mentor, and friend, Ezra. There are plenty of times you think to yourself, "yeah, right, like that'll ever happen", but yet you still watch. The show itself is indulgent and entertaining, but you know it has a shelf life. Moving on to seasons three and four...words and phrases come to mind such as, ridiculous, you can't be serious, and oh come on! There's an old phrase, which I hate, but we all know the phrase people use when a show has outlasted it's welcome. This show absolutely turns to sh*t by season four. The story line and it's characters have all gone off the reservation. Do yourself a favor, save many useless hours of watching, and change the channel after season two. I gave a 6 rating for the overall series, but if I were able I would give the first two seasons a solid 8 and the last two would be a 5. I don't know if it's coming back for a fifth season, but I cannot imagine any further episodes could warrant watching.

reviews.review_title: 5 because the 1st and (almost) 2nd seasons are great
reviews.content: I remember when this show first came out, it was dark and intriguing; I wanted more every episode; figuring out what would happen next and understanding the plot and elements to the story; figuring out the mystery of it all. The second season began in a similar fashion with fantasy-like tendencies (which is not ideal) but again, it worked.... For a bit.Suddenly, I felt like a brand new rookie producer and writing team replaced everyone important. Instantly, Ray devolves into an inhumane Neanderthal with very little emotional connection to anything and his family just completely turns on him while he does *literally* nothing about it, and his brothers go off into their own stories (which seems good, but isn't) that leads to zero substance and sad character arks.Final comments: I ABSOLUTELY HATE the Latina wrestler that becomes Bunchy's BDSM/wife/baby mama. I have NEVERRRRR witnessed something in cinema or television so forced, uncomfortable, and awfully unnecessary. I'm sure whoever had the idea for her character THOUGHT they knew things about sexual abuse to give Bunchy a leg-up for his character, but clearly is living in their own world.Also- Throughout the ENTIRE series; episode one to whatever; the "actor" who plays the son, Connor Donovan, is without a doubt the worst actor on the planet. When you see a show and notice in the pilot a major character is replaced for the second season and on; and you wonder why... Connor Donovan is the answer to that question/curiosity.Bonus: There is a moment in season 3, episode 6 where Ray and Mick come into the Fight Club and Terry is paranoid about a possible intruder. After the gun is out and away, the three characters (father and two sons) have a very quick moment of laughter and happiness, slight vulnerability and genuine character. It's quite beautiful; probably nothing you can think of now. But when you see it, you wished the entire series had this element of life to it.Perhaps a difficult ask for the show's premise, but not impossible.
